2 The application is made by Chief Psychiatrist or delegate or nominee of the Chief Psychiatrist Name Dr Emma Glanville

Position held Consultant Psychiatrist

Report written by Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Mr Nesmith is a 33 yo homeless unemployed gentleman who was referred to our service by his GP on the 15518 and seen my our mental health clinicians on several occasions before his psychiatry assessment on 6th June 2018

Mr Nesmiths initial presentation wascharacterized by quite odd and eccentric beliefs and preoccupations and grandiose themes These manifested more floridly on the 11 June 2018 with concerns he had an untreated psychosis with manic features and an appointment made with Dr Flynn registrar Mr Nesmith consistently insists that he does not believe he has a mental illness nor needing any antipsychotic or other psychiatric medications Our concerns are for his longterm welfare if he remains chronically unwell and associated risks discussed in more detail in sections to follow

MENTAL ILLNESS OR MENTAL DISORDER Use the definitions set out in the glossary at the end of this form

andor a

For mental illness Describe how the illness impairs the persons mental functioning identify the areas offunctioning that are affected by the illness and identify the symptoms that characterise the illness andor the behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence of one or more of the symptoms

In presentations and assessments on the 1st June and 6th June it is apparent that Mr Nesmith has a psychotic

illness characterized by an elaborate systemized delusional system that is very fixed and possibly on a background of a schizotypal personality disorder with longstanding beliefs and suspicion about several organizations infiltrating the government social and medical services including the Illuminati Freemasons and Artificial Intelligence Al

Mr Nesmith seems to spend most of his time gathering evidence of the Freemasons activity in Canberra a place he believes is the Occult Capital of the World He believes the Freemasons do ritualistic and brutal child sacrifices and states he has evidence of this He also spends time recording short films on his phone as part of his evidence and distribution to others to warn them of these organisations infiltrating society and showing proof for example of Al taking control He also spends time writing emails to various organisations eg AFP to alert them of the atrocities of the Freemasons and pleading they take action He presents very earnest and driven to save society from these malevolent organisations and sees himself as a type of saviour He emails

and videos he shows us are more difficult to follow and convey a deeper level of disorganization in his thinking

Mr Nesmith states he has been a student of Philosophy for 10 years recently finishing a degree at Murdoch University It does not seem his was worked though he states he is a successful FilmMaker and has won several awards in Film Festivals overseas It is unclear if Mt Nesmith could hold down any form of employment with the level of his preoccupations and role he has defined for himself in society He also chooses to isolate himself by camping in Mt Ainslie bush area as a way to avoid the malevolent people he believes inhabit the city though he has voiced openness to assistance with more stable housing

Mt Nesmith presents with impeccable manners often very polite but can become more irritable if he feels we are not believing his convictions or discuss mental health illness and treatment At times he has presented with more racing speech elevated and expansive mood and harder to follow in conversations See details in

ASSESSMENT Set out details of your assessment supporting your opinion

Psychiatry Assessment Dr Caroline Flynn 6th June 2018 Transcript of clinical notes

Background

33 yo man homeless itinerant lives in a tent around Mt Ainslie about 40min bushwalk secretive where exactly his is Hos been able to source clothes free1ood from community aid organisations on Newstart has a phone Originally from USA states has been studying Philosophy degree for 10 years 2008 2018 from Murdoch University Describes being estranged from parents and one biological brother Ricky who reside in USA and nil contact for years

Today

Wendell presented today with very elaborate delusions with themes that the world needs saving from the Apocalypse from various malevolent organisations and Al and that it was his duty to warn and save others ond the world at large There wos a lot of grandiosity as well identifies himself as a saviour

He was very preoccupied driven around his beliefs and became irritable if we hypothesized alternatives or seem to doubt him He showed no insight into potentially having a mental illness insisting that I am not crazy there is no way I will go on any antpsychotic and that we have the problems ifwe dont believe him and that we would be part of the coverup and sensoring that has infiltrated all levels of government police and health services

Chronic risks for Wendell is a poor prognosis and recovery the longer a psychotic illness is left untreated that any medical contributors to his psychosis have yet to be investigated and that he likely to stay unemployed itinerant and on the fringe

It is unknown if he would ever act violently based on his delusions There is not enough past known history try and quantitate risk other than his psychotic illness is a risk factor

Seems to have a degree of organisation eg with newstart streetwise about foodgear does not look too dishevelled

Relevant Past History

Mr Nesmith has only had two prior contact periods with our Service

The first was in April 2012 referred by GP resulting in a short involuntary PSU acute adult psychiatric ward admission Canberra Hospital

The referral from GP stated He presented to me with some magical thinking no auditory hallucinations he has no friends and claimed to be Jiving on the mountain There is a family history of schizoid personality disorder I believe he has schizotypal personality disorder

He was seen by CATT clinicians with Mr Nesmith agreeable to coming to hospital for an assessment but he had told CATT that our system will not help that this is the 2 in a psychiatric ward your doctors will diagnose me as either schizophrenia or schizotypal they will force medication on me and push their own ideal of what a

ignoredandstigmaswi1 bepushedonmedoctorswillmisjudgewhattheyseeinfrontofthemandcategorise me your systems do not help BUT no longer care about anything so the follies of your society will have to deal with its creation ME OR I end my life Your choice I no longer care

Mr Nesmith was assessed by a psychiatrist Dr J Cubis who thought he had a likely psychotic illness or schizotypal personality disorder Mr Nesmith was admitted to PSU acute adult mental health unit on 28th April 5th May 2012 Mr Nesmith did not talk or cooperate much with the admission and as he was not floridly psychotic the team could not uphold a PTO so he was discharged and lost contact with services

The second contact was brief in 2013 by the psychiatry CL Canberra Hospital team after a bizarre incident where he had inserted speaker wire into his penis requiring surgical intervention Surgical team referred to psychiatry CL as his speech was hard to follow he had odd behavioursbeliefs and seemed quite paranoid He was initially placed on an ED7 as presented psychotic with thought disorder and grandiose But this was taken off a few days later as he presented more settled with no evidence of psychosis though his odd and eccentric personality paranoid themes and alternate lifestyle camping in bushland near Mt Ainslie to avoid people was noted at the time He was hence discharged and not seen again by our services until this year

When asked about this hospital incident ricently Mr Nesmith talked about being embarrassed it had happened and that it was sexual experimentation that went horribly wrong as he wanting to try and increase sexual stimulation

In regards to other psychiatric presentations Mr Nesmith has spoken about being locked up in hospitals in various places in NSW at least on 2 occasions with him believing he was being censored for his beliefs and part of a greater conspiracy and coverup He was reluctant to give details of his time in hospital or precise locations He could list by name several antipsychotics used olanzapine risperidone quetiapine and the awful side effects experienced adding to his negative experience It does not seem he has ever taken

anti psychotics longterm only in restrictive environments

There is no known history of his earlier years in the US before he moved to Australia He states he is estranged from his US parents and siblings because they dont believe in my cause He is adamant he does not want contact with them We have not found any longerterm friend or contact for any collateral history alas

Describe and explain your overall assessment referring to the factors above and to the principles of decisionmaking capacity set out in section 8 see Glossary

Mr Nesmith does not believe his has a mental illness and that anyone who questions his beliefs or

intentionsis partofthe widespreadcensorship andcoverups Healsobelievesmedica1 staff enforce their own views of societal norms and illness in a biased way and with illintent Any discussion of mental illness or offer of antipsychotic medication is seen as us being judgemental dismissive and at worse part of the conspiracy to keep him from doing his tasks of saving humanity from various threats He has a hint of insight than he can get busy and elevated but only wants Xanax alprazolam to help slow him down He believes this is part of his excitable personality style and not a sign of a mood or psychotic disorder The notion of going to hospital for treatment is also seen as the ultimate punishment alas and he would find this very traumatic and coercive and further proof of the medical establishments malevolence This belief is also based on real past negative experiences with involuntary psychiatric admissions and side effects from several anti psychotics that he reports

REFUSAL

6 Does the person refuse to receive treatment care or support or if the person has decisionmaking

capacity refuse to consent to treatment care or support

IBJYes No

If yes describe what the person does andor says that constitutes refusal

Mr Nesmith is refusing to trial any antipsychotic medication due to his conviction that he does not have a mental illness and that any treatment will be unjust unfounded and cause harm

RISK OR DETERIORATION answer on basis of likelihood if untreated

7 Is the person doing or likely to do serious harm to themselves or someone else because of the mental

illness or mental disorder IBlYes No

Is the person suffering or likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration because of the mental illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

If yes explain your reasons for this opinion

Risk prediction is a fraught area as clinicians cannot be precise or quantitate risk given the variables and unpredictable nature of peoples behaviour and their environments

However the risks to Mr Nesmith include that the longer he is left with an untreated psychotic illness the worse his prognosis and quality of recovery that could have devastating impacts on his ability to work have relationships live and function in society There is a potential risk of him falsely identifying a community member as the grandmaster of the Freemasons based on a delusion and conflict arising with possible violent sequelae although there is no past history of violent altercations yet that we know of His intinerant and secretive lifestyle limits any corroborative history He may be at risk of angering others with his investigations and misadventure There are risks around camping in the bush regions if he was to have physical health issues or not have enough gear for w rmth Personal safety and security is also problematic

Is is not known if Mr Nesmith would selfharm if he became overwhelmed by his predicament and fate

of the world There was the past incident of inserting a wire into his penis which may have been due

incidents to self

TREATMENT

8 What treatment care or support is proposed If a treatment plan is prepared it may be attached to this form

It is unlikely given his lack of insight that Mr Nesmith would agree to trial an oral anti psychotic in the community and be adherent Hence a treatment trial would involve a hospital environment with the goals of starting an oral antipsychotic eg paliperidone or aripiprazole and switching to a depot preparation Several weeks would be required and the inpatient setting choices include the Acute Adult Mental Health Unit at Canberra Hospital or possibly a rehabilitation facility that may be less stressful for him

Community followup would include regular contact with a casemanager and doctor psychological therapy if desired and assistance linking to services for housing and other goals he may have in his recovery eg further study or work

9 Why or how will treatment care or support be Hkely to reduce harm or deterioration or result in an improvement to the persons condition

It is hoped that Mr Nesmiths delusional preoccupations are reversible and that with treatment he would be able to not be so consumed in saving the world collect evidence confronting organisations etc and transfer his intellect and creativity to other pursuits that hopefully provide joy fulfillment and security and not place him at risk The risks associated with chronic mental illness would hopefully be reduced and his quality of life improved There is a possibility that he is estranged from his US family due to delusional beliefs and this could potentially be healed and increase his supports

10 Why cant the treatment ca _cr upport a_eq_ ae y prov1 e w1 es r of choice and movement of the person

Primarily because Mr Nesmith will not consent to treatment in the community setting and is likely to disengage from our services entirely if he feels we are a threat to his liberty Any reasonable treatment trial will involve at least 48 weeks of adequate dose medication

Dr Emma Glanville

Dr Emma Glanville

MBBS MP FRANZCP

Consultant Psychiatrist City Mental Health

1 Moore Street Canberra ACT 2601

Ph 02 62051338 Provider No 236841 NY

Full name of Applicant relevant official or delegate or nominee of the Chief Psychiatrist

Page 11 of 14

GLOSSARY

Section 10 Meaning of mental ifness

In this Act

mental illness means a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permanently the mental functioning of a person inl or more areas of thought mood volition perception orientation or memory and is characterised by

a the presence ofat least 1 of the following symptoms

i delusions

ii hallucinations

iii serious disorders of streams of thought

iv serious disorders of thought form

v serious disturbance of mood or

b sustained or repeated irrational behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence of at least 1 of the symptoms mentioned in paragraph a

Section 9 Meaning of mental disorder

In this Act

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Page 12 of 14

mental disorder

a means a disturbance or defect to a substantially disabling degree of perceptual inteqiretation comprehension reasoning learning judgment memory motivation or emotion but

b does not include a condition that is a mental illness

Section 7 Meaning of decisionmaking capacity

For this Act a person has capacity to make a decision in relation to the persons treatment care or support for a mental disorder or mental illness decisionmaking capacity if the person can with assistance if needed

a understand when a decision about treatment care or support for the person needs to be made and

b understand the facts that relate to the decision and

c understand the main choices available to the person in relation to the decision and

d weigh up the consequences of the main choices and

e understand how the consequences affect the person and

f on the basis of paragraphs a to e make the decision and

g communicate the decision in whatever way the person can

Section 8 Principles of decisionmaking capacity

1 In considering a persons decisionmalcing capacity under this Act the following principles must be taken into account

a a persons ec1s1onm ang capac1 1 p u o 1 1 n

ii a person must be assumed to have decisionmalcing capacity unless it is established that the

person does not have decisionmaking capacity

c a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must always be supported to make decisions about the persons treatment care or support to the best of the persons ability

d a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity unless all practicable steps to assist the person to make decisions have been taken

e a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity only because

i the person malces an unwise decision or

ii the person has impaired decisionmaking capacity under another Act or in relation to another decision

f a person must not be treated as having decisionmalcing capacity to consent to the provision of treatment care or support only because the person complies with the provision of the treatment care or support

g a person who moves between having and not having decisionmaking capacity must if reasonably practicable be given the opportunity to consider matters requiring a decision at a time when the person has decisionmaking capacity

2 A persons decisionmaking capacity must always be talcen into account in deciding treatment care or support unless this Act expressly provides otherwise

3 An act done or decision made under this Act for a person who does not have decisionmalcing capacity must be done in the persons best interests

4 In considering a persons decisionmalcing capacity under this Act any approved code of practice under section 198 must be taken into account

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Printed By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar Page 13 of 14

In respect of WENDELL CHARLES NESMITH

PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT ORDER

The Tribunal Orders

1 The Tribunal makes a Psychiatric Treatment Order in relation to Wendell Charles Nesmith

2 Wendell Charles Nesmith must comply with any determination made by the Chief Psychiatrist or delegate under section 62 of the Mental Health Act 2015

3 Unless sooner revoked this order has effect for 6 months

The Tribunal notes

a This order will be reviewed on its own motion prior to expiry

STATEMENT

i

ii

This statement sets out how Wendell Charles Nesmith meets the criteria for a psychiatric treatment order under section 582 of the Mental Health Act 2015 The findings in the statement are based on the information before the Tribunal and are made on the balance of probabilities

Wendell Charles Nesmith has a mental illness because he has a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permanently his mental ctioning in

areas incl ding hought nd moodhich s characterised1heFpr e ce of symptoms including delusions and serious disturbance of moqd 9

I 3

_r _ J

iii Wendell Charles Nesmith does not have decisionmaking capacity to c6risertt o the treatment care or support because he cannot undersfrid wlf n n about his treatment care or support needs to be made t eci Ql1 ot weigh up the consequ nces of the main choices he ca dt Q_de a tf the consequences affect him and he cannot make the dec1s1on o fba 1 of the matters set out above

iv Wendell Charles Nesmith refuses the treatment determined in relation to himself because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with treatment The Tribunal considers his current compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment

v The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to do serious harm to himself as a result of misadventure or self neglect when unwell

vi The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

vii The Tribunal is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or support is likely to reduce the likelihood of harm or deterioration mentioned above and is likely to result in an improvement in Wendell Charles Nesmiths psychiatric condition

viii The Tribunal is satisfied that the treatment care or support to be provided under tte psychiatric treatment order cannot be adequately provided in another way that would involve less restriction of Wendell Charles Nesmiths freedom of choice

Dear Mr Nesmith

Changes to ways you can access our services

I am writing to you following your contact with us at Braddon Service Centre on 4 July 2018

During this contact you were disruptive in the Service Centre and refused to leave when directed to do so

As we discussed on 4 July 2018 this behaviour is not acceptable You must act with courtesy and respect towards our staff and other customers at all times

Your service arrangement

As a result of your behaviour on this occasion and to maintain the safety of our staff and customers I have decided to limit the ways you can access our services

Your service arrangement will start from 4 July 2018 and end on 10 July 2018 During this period you may only contact us by

calling your One Main Contact Sam on 02 6211 3490 If Sam is not available you can call Ashley on 02 6200 5327

humanservicesgovaucontact

use the services of a Departmental Agent or Access Point for Centrelink Medicare andor Child Support business

Section 91 of the Mental Health Act 2015 requires the release of Wendell Charles Nesmith as soon as practicable before the period of further detention expires if his detention under section 85 is no longer justified

Evidence that the person requires immediate treatment care or support

Mr Nesmith is a 34 year old male known to ACT MHS with previous admissions for psychosis who was brought to The Canberra Hospital Emergency Department by police under an Emergency Assessment order after becoming aggressive and agitated at a Medicare Office He currently presents as elevated grandiose disorganised and poorly kempt He has significant delusional thought content regarding artificial intelligence electronic frequencies in his brain and not being human Mr Nesmith reports that he currently resides in a tent in the bush in Canberra with no permanent address

Report written by Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

3 vvhy are you making thisappltcatloTriDestrtbiffulevant ever1tsiirtitltrrg1trtlfuiipplltatfuit

Mr Nesmith is a 33 yo homeless unemployed gentleman who was referred to our service by his GP on the 15518 and seen my our mental health clinicians on several occasions before his psychiatry assessment on 6th June 2018

Mr Nesmiths initial presentation wascharacterized by quite odd and eccentric beliefs and preoccupations and grandiose themes These manifested more floridly on the 1st June 2018 with concerns he had an untreated psychosis with manic features and an appointment made with Dr Flynn registrar Mr Nesmith consistently insists that he does not believe he has a mental illness nor needing any antipsychotic or other psychiatric medications Our concerns are for his longterm welfare if he remains chronically unwell and associated risks discussed in more detail in sections to follow

MENTAL ILLNESS OR MENTAL DISORDER Use the definitions set out in the glossary at the end of this form

4 The person has a mental illness mental disorder

xYes o No

o Yes x No

andor a

For mental illness Describe how the illness impairs the persons mental functioning identify the areas of functioning that are affected by the illness and Identify the symptoms that characterise the Illness andor the behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence ofone or more of the symptoms

In presentations and assessments on the 1st June and 6th June it is apparent that Mr Nesmith has a psychotic

illness characterized by an elaborate systemized delusional system that is very fixed and possibly on a background of a schizotypal personality disorder with longstanding beliefs and suspicion about several organizations infiltrating the government social and medical services including the Illuminati Freemasons and Artificial Intelligence Al

Mr Nesmith seems to spend most of his time gathering evidence of the Freemasons activity in Canberra a place he believes is the Occult Capital of the World He believes the Freemasons do ritualistic and brutal child sacrifices and states he has evidence of this He also spends time recording short films on his phone as part of his evidence and distribution to others to warn them of these organisations infiltrating society and showing proof for example of Al taking control He also spends time writing emails to various organisations eg AFP to alert them of the atrocities of the Freemasons and pleading they take action He presents very earnest and driven to save society from these malevolent organisations and sees himself as a type of saviour He emails

and videos he shows us are more difficult to follow and convey a deeper level of disorganization in his thinking

Mr Nesmith states he has been a student of Philosophy for 10 years recently finishing a degree at Murdoch University It does not seem his was worked though he states he is a successful FilmMaker and has won several awards in Film Festivals overseas It is unclear if Mt Nesmith could hold down any form of employment with the level of his preoccupations and role he has defined for himself in society He also chooses to isolate himself by camping in Mt Ainslie bush area as a way to avoid the malevolent people he believes inhabit the city though he has voiced openness to assistance with more stable housing

Mt Nesmith presents with impeccable manners often very polite but can become more irritable if he feels we are not believing his convictions or discuss mental health illness and treatment At times he has presented with more racing speech elevated and expansive mood and harder to follow in conversations See details in

aSsessmeet0otefuU0wJa _

ASSESSMENT Set out details of your assessment supporting your opinion Psychiatry Assessment Dr Caroline Flynn 6th June 2018

Transcript of clinical notes

Background

33 yo man homeless itinerant lives in a tent around Mt Ainslie about 40min bushwalk secretive where exactly his is Has been able to source clothes free1ood from community aid organisations on Newstart has a phone

Originally from USA states has been studying Philosophy degree for 10 years 2008 2018 from Murdoch

i University Describes being estranged from parents and one biological brother Ricky who reside in USA and nil contact for years

Recently seen by AATworkers and has presented very grandiose manic Today

Wendell presented today with vey elaborate delusions with themes that the world needs saving from the

Apocalypse from various malevolent organisations and Al and that it was his duty to warn and save others and the world at large There was a lot of grandiosity as well Identifies himself as a saviour

He was very preoccupied driven around his beliefs and became irritable if we hypothesized alternatives or seem to doubt him He showed no insight into potentially having a mental illness insisting that I am not crazy there is no way I will go on any antpsychotic and that we have the problems ifwe dont believe him and that we would be part of the coverup and sensoring that has infiltrated all levels of government police and health services

Did say he gets elevated because he is passionate and people think this is a mental illness but challenged societal norms and upset he has been labelled in past as being unwell

Whilst Wendell liked to be very polite and call me mam could smile and be gracious rapport was brittle

when he felt under scrutiny challengednot believed But he contained the irritability displaying it in more driven proof speech wanting to show evidence on his phone

Tolerated redirection and interruptions Content of his interview included

Described himself as a Philosopher who integrates mythology eg showing that Peter Pan is real sociology

and other cultural subject to explain the truth about society

Called himself an ward winning filmmaker with a recent prize at the Social Uprising Grassroot and Resistancefilm festival in the US Film was a private release to avoid censorship called Ivory Heart

He believes Canberra is the occult capital of the World

He thinks the Freemasons are a satanic cult that sacrifice children and that the Grandmaster is in Canberra He is investigating them documenting them and has proof to show others eg police of their crimes and he wants to take over the Freemasons to save everyone from them

There is no person he has specifically identified still looking but states he has all the evidence

He described a bizzare belief in a ritual that the Freemasons do including sucking the blood from an artery to use the effects of substances from the adrenal gland for powerhealth

He believes that Artificial Intelligence Al is taking over the world That Al has integrated into oil our technology and creating synthetic bodies to appear as humans

Wendall showed usavideo part of went for45mins we watchedabout5minshe createdon hisiphone titled War games as proof of this

It was an amateur footage of trees and o Canberra building with a voice over that didnt make much sense but

then footage of another phone with a Siritype animation lady answering his questions about the Freemasons

Answered seemed autogenerated from a sirilike assistant program but Wendall was adamant this was an example of Als capabilities and manevolent intent

Wendall believes he is now the head of the 1luminat who use to be an organisation intent on taking over the world as well but he stopped this Hence his focus now on the Freemasons and Al

Wendall also read a long email he sent to to the AFP yesterday detailing his beliefs that the Freemasons have infiltrated them and his proof of the Freemasons evil and that they should act etc Although the sentence structure was logical his ideas were difficult to follow at times included a reference to a pineal gland

1 addiction and mentioning atrocities without defining them

Also described on a mission looking for his wife that he reference some attachment spiritually at birth and it is his quest to find her Tattoo on chest was a name he has given her but yet to find her real name Also showed various tattoos that had religious or other special significance in his various quests

I tried to explore with Wendell any past psychiatric treatmentexperiences

He states he has been imprisoned in Canberra Grafton and 12 other psychiatric hospitals in Australia He believes this was due to trying to censor him Adamant he has never had mental health problems

He has had olanzapine in the past and found it awful very sedatingflattening and felt it was done with malevolent intent

He states risperidone was even worse but didnt give specifics as started to get irritable about me watching to

push medications on him Hates seroquel

Wont consider anything new eg Abilify as does not believe he needs it and thinks we are pushing medication to censor him or for some other ill intent or for our benefitgain

Only medication he would accept is Xanax for when he felt he need to restslow down Explained rarely

prescribed now and why Seemed to accept this and did not push for script

DA

Wendell denies any illict drug use eg cannabis Ice ecstacy synthetics

However he states he buys herbs from the chemist and smokes those sometimes Nil alcohol

Nicotine stains noted on fingers

Medical

nil medical history of note disclosed states he is very healthy fit and strong nil physical complaintsconcerns

Agrees he hasnt had blood testsor a long time and agreeable to have some done Agreeable to finding a GP

Family

Wendell wasnt keen to talk about this family

He states his parents are in USA

He has not contacted them for years as they do not believe in what he is doing

Same with his one biological brother Ricky

Also states his parents adopted 2731 children around the world

Friends

states he has a few close friends but did not want to elaborate

Risk

Wendell is intent on finding the Freemasons and confronting people if he suspects that are them or to tell them his views about needing to be warnedsaved He agreed some people wont listen to him but thathehad to try There was no single person he had identified yet in his evidence I dont know yet I am still looking

He would like to challenge the grandmaster in hand to hand combat but no way would I killhurt him I am

a pacifist I just want to be the new leader of the Freemasons like I did with the Illuminati His proof of leadership of the Illuminati was not from a combat challenge but an email he sentto a princess which he showed us and didnt make much sense and I noted email address had rebounded as undelivered

He denies any thought or intent to hurt someone even if he felt for example they had sacrificed children

He denied any problems with police and has never been aggressivethreatened people

He was upset that I asked about this as it went against his ethicsmorals

Wendells biggest current risk is potentially aggravating others with his driven beliefs and conflict arising Misadventure from his homelessness and living in a tent in a harsh approaching winter could be a problem

There is aso the past risk incident when he inserted a speaker wire into his penis 2013 and the possibility of further incidents if based on a delusional belief

Chronic risks for Wendell is a poor prognosis and recovery the longer a psychotic illness is left untreated that any medical cantributors to his psychosis have yet to be investigated and that he likely to stay unemployed itinerant and on the fringe

It is unknown if he would ever act violently based on his delusions There is not enough past known history try and quantitate risk other than his psychotic illness is a risk factor

Seems to hove o degree of organisation eg with newstort streetwise about foodgear does not look too dishevelled

Stated he hod challenged the Freemasons to send their best warrior and the next day o guy who was o gong

noted buttheperson received the head butt ondfeetothe ground Wendell reportshewoswith2other moles He reported this incident to the AFP Simone and hos not pressed charges

Mr Nesmith was assessed by a psychiatrist Dr J Cubis who thought he had a likely psychotic illness or schizotypal personality disorder Mr Nesmith was admitted to PSU acute adult mental health unit on 28th April 5th May 2012 Mr Nesmith did not talk or cooperate much with the admission and as he was not floridly psychotic the team could not uphold a PTO so he was discharged and lost contact with services

Mr Nesmith is refusing to trial any antipsychotic medication due to his conviction that he does not have a mental illness and that any treatment will be unjust unfounded and cause harm

RISK OR DETERIORATION answer on basis of likelihood if untreated

7 Is the person doing or likely to do serious harm to themselves or someone else because of the mental

illness or mental disorder IBlYes No

Is the person suffering or likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration because of the mental illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

If yes explain your reasons for this opinion

Risk prediction is a fraught area as clinicians cannot be precise or quantitate risk given the variables and unpredictable nature of peoples behaviour and their environments

However the risks to Mr Nesmith include that the longer he is left with an untreated psychotic illness the worse his prognosis and quality of recovery that could have devastating impacts on his ability to work have relationships live and function in society There is a potential risk of him falsely identifying a community member as the grandmaster of the Freemasons based on a delusion and conflict arising with possible violent sequelae although there is no past history of violent altercations yet that we know of His intinerant and secretive lifestyle limits any corroborative history He may be at risk of angering others with his investigations and misadventure There are risks around camping in the bush regions if he was to have physical health issues or not have enough gear for Wrmth Personal safety and security is also problematic

Is is not known if Mr Nesmith would selfharm if he became overwhelmed by his predicament and fate of the world There was the past incident of inserting a wire into his penis which may have been due

butlikely given msmental state postoperat1on anhence poss1blefutUre risk of other such risky incidents to self

TREATMENT

8 What treatment care or support is proposed If a treatment plan is prepared it may be attached to this form

It is unlikely given his lack of insight that Mr Nesmith would agree to trial an oral anti psychotic in the community and be adherent Hence a treatment trial would involve a hospital environment with the goals of starting an oral anti psychotic eg paliperidone or aripiprazole and switching to a depot preparation Several weeks would be required and the inpatient setting choices include the Acute Adult Mental Health Unit at Canberra Hospital or possibly a rehabilitation facility that may be less stressful for him

Community followup would include regular contact with a casemanager and doctor psychological therapy if desired and assistance linking to services for housing and other goals he may have in his recovery eg further study or work

9 Why or how will treatment care or support be likely to reduce harm or deterioration or result in an improvement to the persons condition

It is hoped that Mr Nesmiths delusional preoccupations are reversible and that with treatment he would be able to not be so consumed in saving the world collect evidence confronting organisations etc and transfer his intellect and creativity to other pursuits that hopefully provide joy fulfillment and security and not place him at risk The risks associated with chronic mental illness would hopefully be reduced and his quality of life improved There is a possibility that he is estranged from his US family

due to delusional beliefs and this could potentially be healed and increase his supports

Primarily because Mr Nesmith will not consent to treatment in the community setting and is likely to disengage from our services entirely if he feels we are a threat to his liberty Any reasonable treatment trial will involve at least 48 weeks of adequate dose medication

GLOSSARY

Section 10 Meaning of mental illness

In this Act

mental illness means a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permauently the mental functioning of a person inl or more areas of thought mood volition perception orientation or memory and is characterised by

a the presence of at least 1 of the following symptoms

i delusions

ii hallucinations

iii serious disorders of streams of thought

iv serious disorders of thought fonn

v sedous disturbance of mood or

b sustained or repeated irrational behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence of at least 1 of the symptoms mentioned in paragraph a

Section 9 Meaning of mental disorder

In this Act

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Page 12 of 14

mental disorde1

a means a disturbance or defect to a substantially disabling degree of perceptual interpretation comprehension reasoning learning judgment memo1y motivation or emotion but

b does not include a condition that is a mental illness

Section 7 Meaning of decisionmaking capacity

For this Act a person has capacity to make a decision in relation to the persons treatment care or support for a mental disorder or mental illness decisionmaking capacity if the person can with assistance if needed

a understand when a decision about treatment care or support for the person needs to be made and

b understand the facts that relate to the decision and

c understand the main choices available to the person in relation to the decision and

d weigh up the consequences of the main choices and

e understand how the consequences affect the person and

f on the basis of paragraphs a to e make the decision and

g communicate the decision in whatever way the person can

Section 8 Principles of decisionmaking capacity

1 In considering a persons decisionmaking capacity under this Act the following principles must be taken into account

a a persons dec1s10n 111alang capacity is partTouiarfuihedeclliion that lfie petson 1s to make

bapersonmustbeassumed to iiave dedsTon 1nalcmg capadtymiless iflsestabffshedtliatthe

person does not have decisionmaking capacity

c a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must always be supported to make decisions about the persons treatment care or support to the best of the persons ability

d a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity unless all practicable steps to assist the person to make decisions have been taken

e a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity only because

i the person makes an unwise decision or

ii the person has impaired decisionmaking capacity under another Act or in relation to another decision

f a person must not be treated as having decisionmaking capacity to consent to the provision of treatment care or support only because the person complies with the provision of the treatment care or support

g a person who moves between having and not having decisionmaking capacity must if reasonably practicable be given the opportunity to consider matters requiring a decision at a time when the person has decisionmaking capacity

2 A persons decisionmaking capacity must always be taken into account in deciding treatment care or support unless this Act expressly provides otherwise

3 An act done or decision made under this Act for a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must be done in the persons best interests

4 In considering a persons decisionmaldng capacity under this Act any approved code of practice under section 198 must be taken into account

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Eligibility for Legal Aid is determined by the Commissions Guidelines We look carefully at your financial eligibility the merits of your case and whether it complies with requirements of the Legal Aid Act

Taking into account these guidelines your application for legal assistance has been refused because it is not reasonable to spend scarce legal aid funds in circumstances where prospects of success are outside our guidelines of more likely than not to succeed

You can ask for this decision to be reconsidered If you want to do so please send your request in writing to Client Services within 28 days

Yours sincerely

Client Services Legal Aid ACT Ph 6243 3411

Fax 6243 3435

clientserviceslegalaidACTorgau

GENERAL CONDITIONS OF LEGAL ASSISTANCE

Your obligations

1 Your initial contribution towards the cost of the legal work covered by the grant of legal assistance is noted on the reverse side of this document You must pay this contribution to your lawyer at your next appointment

2 We may reassess the amount of your contribution and increase it even up to 100 of the full cost of providing assistance Call our Client Services staff on 6243 3411 if you want to know more about the circumstances in which your contribution might be increased

3 If your lawyer receives any money on your behalf they must keep sufficient aside to pay us any contribution that you owe Contributions are paycib1e on demand If you are having difficulty paying your contribution you may ask us if you can payyinsfafments

4 If you or 4oneen whom you depend for financial support owns any land eg a house er unit we may make it a condiion of the grant of legal assistance that we take a charge over that land to secure payment of your contribution

5 You must notify us imrnediately if there is any change in your financial situation or if you change address

6 If you do net accept your lawyers advice your grant of legal assistance may be stopped

7 You must get our approval before you change your lawyer If you do change your lawyer you may have to pay additional costs because of this

8 The documents we hold concerning your grant of legal assistance will be destroyed seven years after the grant is completed unless you ask us to make other arrangements

Your rights of review

9 For most decisions we make you may request a reconsideration if you are not satisfied with the decision The request must be made in writing within 28 days of receiving notice of the decision If you are not satisfied with the result of the reconsideration you may request an independent review of the decision The request for review must be made in writing within 28 days of notification of the result of the reconsideration

10 Legal Aid ACT will be impartial and open in our dealings with you We will provide accurate information within a reasonable timeframe

Your lawyers obligations

11 Your lawyer has been authorised by us to do the work described in the grant of assistance up to the commitment limit set in the grant If more work needs to be done your lawyer must first ask us to extend the grant of assistance

12 Your lawyer must not ask you to pay anything towards the cost of work covered by the grant of assistance other than your contribution

13 Your lawyer must give us reports on the progress of your case and details of any offers to settle the case As your case progresses your lawyer must provide a report on the outcomes reached and an account setting out the work they have done and the cost of that work

14 Your lawyer must make their file available to us if we ask to see it

15 Your lawyer must comply with professional standards as a legal practitioner and also comply with practice standards developed by Legal Aid ACT for legal assistance work The practice standards can be viewed on the Legal Aid ACT website wwwlegalaidactorgau

If you want a further explanation of any of these terms and conditions please contact Client Services on 6243 3411 during business hours

I refer to your request for reconsideration of the decision to refuse you a grant of assistance in this matter Upon reconsideration it is necessary pursuant to section 39 of the Legal Aid Act 1977 to have regard to funds available to the Commission and to the nature and extent of the legal assistance that has been provided from those funds Those funds are limited

In reconsidering your application for a grant of legal assistance I am bound to follow the Legal Aid Act 1977 and the Legal Assistance Guidelines the Guidelines made thereunder I have carefully considered your reconsideration request and the documents on your file however I regret to advise I now confirm the decision to refuse you a grant of legal assistance in this matter because it is not reasonable to spend scarce legal aid funds in circumstances where prospects of success are outside our guidelines of more likely than not to succeed

3 Why are you making this application Describe relevant events leading to the application

GLOSSARY

Section 10 Meaning of mental illness

In this Act

mental illness means a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permanently the mental functioning of a person inl or more areas of thought mood volition perception orientation or memory and is characterised by

a the presence of at least 1 of the following symptoms

i delusions

ii hallucinations

iii serious disorders of streams of thought

iv seriousdisorders of thought form

v serious disturbance of mood or

b sustained or repeated irrational behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence of at least I of the symptoms mentioned in paragraph a

Section 9 Meaning of mental disorder

In this Act

mental disorder

a means a disturbance or defect to a substantially disabling degree of perceptual inte1pretation comprehension reasoning learning judgment memory motivation or emotion but

b does not include a condition that is a mental illness

Section 7 Meaning of decisionmaking capacity

For this Act a person has capacity to make a decision in relation to the persons treatment care or support for a mental disorder or mental illness decisionmalcing capacity if the person can with assistance if needed

a understand when a decision about treatment care or support for the person needs to be

made and

b understand the facts that relate to the decision and

c understand the main choices available to the person in relation to the decision and

d weigh up the consequences of the main choices and

e understand how the consequences affect the person and

f on the basis of paragraphs a to e make the decision and

g communicate the decision in whatever way the person can

Section 8 Principles of decisionmaking capacity

1 In considering a persons decisionmaking capacity under this Act the following principles must be taken into account

a a persons decisionmaking capacity is particular to the decision that the person is to make

b a person must be assumed to have decisionmaldng capacity unless it is established that the person does not have decisionmaking capacity

c a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must always be supported to make

decisions about the persons treatment care or support to the best of the persons ability

d a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity unless all practicable steps to assist the person to make decisions have been talen

e a person must not be treated as not having decisionmalcing capacity only because

i the person malces an unwise decision or

ii the person has impaired decisionmaking capacity under another Act or in relation to another decision

f a person must not be treated as having decisionmaking capacity to consent to the provision of treatment care or support only because the person complies with the provision of the treatment care or support

g a person who moves between having and not having decisionmaking capacity must if reasonably practicable be given the opportunity to consider matters requiring a decision at a time when the person has decisionmaking capacity

2 A persons decisionmaking capacity must always be taken into account in deciding treatment care or support unless this Act expressly provides otherwise

3 An act done or decision made under this Act for aperson who does not have decisionmaking capacity must be done in the persons best interests

4 In considering a persons decisionmaking capacity under this Act any approved code of practice under section 198 must be talrnn into account

PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT ORDER

The Tribunal Orders

1 The Tribunal makes a Psychiatric Treatment Order in relation to Wendell Charles Nesmith

2 Wendell Charles Nesmith must comply with any determination made by the Chief Psychiatrist or delegate under section 62 of the Mental Health Act 2015

3 Unless sooner revoked this order has effect for 6 months

The Tribunal notes

a This order will be reviewed on its own motion prior to expiry

STATEMENT

i This statement sets out how Wendell Charles Nesmith meets the criteria for a psychiatric treatment order under section 582 of the Mental Health Act 2015 The findings in the statement are based on the information before the Tribunal and are made on the balance of probabilities 1fr

tf_i C tl l

ii Wendell Charles Nesmith has a mental Hness because he has ionditj g that

seriou y im airs either temporarily o pemanently is men iifLJfRii li l

areas mcl dmg hough hd mood hch is characterised by g_e 1

symptoms mcludmg delusions and serious disturbance of mood 11r0Jf

iii Wendell Chares Nesmith does not have decisionmaking capaci063Jpilj 1t1st9tf the treatment care or support because he cannot understand wheniAfealsidn about his treatment care or support needs to be made the decision he cannot weigh up the consequences of thEJ main choices he cannot understand how the consequences affect him and he cannot make the decision on the basis of the

matters set out above

iv Wendell Charles Nesmith refuses the treatment determined in relation to himself because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with treatment The Tribunal considers his current compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment

v The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to do serious harm to himself as a result of misadventure or self neglect when unwell

vi The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

vii

I

The Tribunal is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or support is likely to reciuce the likelihood of harm or deterioration mentioned above and is likely to result in an improvement in Wendell Charles Nesmiths psychiatric condition

not part of the legal test The legal test is actually does he have a mental illness whats the risk if not treated and then this key question is he refusing treatment

5 Both Dr Davies and I are of the view that there should be a treatment order for six months and the reason why is because when we look at those medical records we see a history of a person who continually says to the authorities that he will accept treatment and then it all goes wrong and hes not involved in treatment any more So just for the purposes of remembering that the best

Illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

Is the person suffering or likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration because of the mental Illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

Jfyes explain your reasons for this opinion

Risk prediction is a fraught area as clinicians cannot be precise or quantltate risk given the variables and unpredictable nature of peoples behaviour and their environments

However the risks to Mr Nesmith Include that the longer he Is left with an untreated psychotic Illness the worse his prognosis and quality of recovery that could have devastating Impacts on his ability to work have relationships Jive and function In society There Is a potential risk of him falsely Identifying a community member as the grandmaster of the Freemasons based on a delusion and conflict arising with possible violent sequelae although there Is no past history of violent altercations yet that we know of His lntlnerant and secretlv lifestyle limits any corroborative history He may be at risk of angering others with his investigations and misadventure There are risks around camping In the bush regions If he was to have physical health issues or not have enough gear for w rmth Personal safety and security Is also problematic

Is is not known if Mr Nesmith would selfharm If he became overwhelmed by his predicament and fate of the world There was the past lncldeht of Inserting a wire Into his penis which may have been due

TREATMENT

8 What treatment care or support Is proposed If a treatment plan is prepared it may be attached to this form

It Is unlikely given his lack of Insight that Mr Nesmith would agree to trial an oral antlpsychotlc In the community and be adherent Hence a treatment trial would Involve a hospital environment with the goals of starting an oral antlpsychotlc eg pallperldone or arlplprazole and switching to a depot preparation Several weeks would be required and the Inpatient setting choices Include the Acute Adult Mental Health Unit at Canberra Hospital or possibly a rehabilitat1on facility that may be less stressful for him

Community followup would Include regular contact with a casemanager and doctor psychological therapy If desired and assistance linking to services for housing and other goals he may have In his recovery eg further study or work

9 Why or how will treatment care or support be likely to reduce harm or deterioration or result in an Improvement to the persons condltloni

It Is hoped thut Mr Nesmlths delusional preoccupations are reversible and that with treatment he would be able to not be so consumed In saving the world collect evidence confronting organisations etc and transfer his Intellect and creativity to other pursuits that hopefully provide Joy fulfillment and security and not place him at risk The risks associated with chronic mental Illness would hopefully be reduced and his quality of life Improved There Is a possibility that he Is estranged from his US family

due to delusional beliefs and this could potentially be healed and Increase his supports

3 Reasons why the appeal should proceed

I refer to the decision that was madeby Presidential Member Daniel on 2 August 2018 to make a 6 month Psychiatric Treatment Order

PTO Mr Nesmith was represented by on a duty basis by Legal Aid ACT at the time of the hearing Questionoflaw 01factinvolved

The basis of Mr Nesmith1s appeal is that the Tribunal erred 1nits decision to grant the PTO as there wns insufficient evidence to satisfy all

of the elements under section 58 of the Mental Health Act 2015

Specifically section 582bii as there was no evidence to suggest that Mr Nesmith was refusing treabnent and the evidence befote the Ttibunal_confirmed that Mr Nesmith had been compliant with the directions of the treating team

Fu1ther there was insufficient evidence to satisfy section 582c i and ii as there was no evidence to show thatMr Nesmith was a serious 1isk to himself or others1 or that he was at11sk of detedmation

Reasons why the appeal should proceed

The Appellant kindly requests that in the interest of justice the Tribunal grant an extension to the 28 dayperiod Mr Nesmith was granted legal assistance on 30 August 2019 allowing him to rnceivelegal advice and representation duringthe appeal process Jnstmctions were obtained after the appeal period expired and this BJlpeal has been filed pro11ptly thereafter

IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY CIVlL AND ADMINISTRATIVE TRIBUNAL

MH 1082012

In respect of WENDELL CHARLES NESMITH

DOB 27061984

Tribunal Presidential Member MT Daniel Senior Member L Drew

Member R Davies

Pate of Order 2 August 2018

PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT ORDER

The Tribunal Orders

1 The Tribunal makes a Psychiatric Treatment Orde_r in relation to Wendell Charles Nesmith

2 Wendell Charles Nesmith must comply With any determination made by the Chief Psychiatrist or delegate under section 62 of the Mental Health Act 2015

3 Unless sooner revoked this order has effect for 6 months

The Tribunal notes

a This order will be reviewed on its own motion prior to expiry

STATEMENT

i This statement sets out how Wendell Charles Nesmith meets the criteria for a psychiatric treatment order under section 582 of the Mental Health Act 2015

The findings in the siatemeht are based on the information before the Tribunal

and are made on the balance of probabilities

c1 f117J

l

iii

Wendell Charles Nesmith has a mental illness because he has dcmditJth that

se_riou ly impairs either temporarily Cl pemanently Is menalf4ii Xifn_m1 areas including thought and mood which 1s characterised by ae Flf_lJ Ji J f _

symptoms including delusions and serious disturbance of mood

iii Wendell Charles Nesmith does not have decisionmaking capaci fll P11fl the treatment care or support because he cannot understand whena derns1on about his treatment care or support needs to be made the decision he cannot weigh up the consequences of th main choices he cannot understand how the consEqUEnces ciffect him and he cannot make the decision on the basis of the matters set out above

iv Wendell Charles Nesmith refuses the treatment determined in relation to himself because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with trec1tment The Tribunal considers his current compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment

v The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to do serious harm to himself as a result of misadventure or self neglect when unwell

vi The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental fllness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

vii

C

The Tribunal is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or supiort is likely to reduce the likelihood of harm or deterioration mentioned above and is likely to result in an improvement in Wendell Charles Nesmiths psychiatric condition

IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY CIVIL AND ADMINISTRATIVE TRIBUNAL

Wendell Charles Nesmith

ACT Chief Psychiatrist

AA 422018

SUBMISSION IN RESPECT OF THE APPELLANTS WEBSITE

1 The Respondent does not oppose the Appeal Tribunal accessing the Appellants website before the hearing for the purpose of assessing its content

Procedural History

2 By email to the Respondent and the Tribunal dated 25 October 2018 the Appellant indicated he wished to submit his the entire site of nesmithnet into evidence in the appeal

3 By email dated 26 October 2018 the Appeal Tribunal invited the Respondent to make written submissions about whether it should access the website before the hearing for the purpose of assessing its content The Appeal Tribunal indicated that it has not yet ruled on whether to admit the contents of the Appellants website into evidence in the appeal

Nature of the appeal and the power to admit new evidence

4 Section 793 of the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 2008 ACAT Act provides that a party to an original application that has been decided by the Tribunal may appeal that decision on a question of law or fact

5 Section 82 of the ACAT Act permits the Appeal Tribunal as it considers appropriate to deal with the appeal

a as a new application or

b as a review of all or part of the original decision

6 The Tribunal has indicated that the appeal hearing will proceed under s 82b as a review of the original decision Directions 24 September 2018 email of26 October 2018

Filed for the Respondent by

ACT Government Solicitor

Contact

Kate Smyth

Level 5 12 Moore Street

Tel

02 6207 6483

CANBERRA CITY ACT 2601

Fax

02 6207 0650

PO Box 260 CIVIC SQUARE ACT 2608

Email

katesmythactgovau

DX 5602 CANBERRA

Ref

635075

7 In an appeal by way ofreview under s 82b of the ACAT Act

the Appellant must demonstrate an eTor of fact or law or an erroneous exercise of discretion and

the Appeal Tribunal may receive futther evidence1

8 The Respondent submits that the factors relevant to determining whether to admit further evidence in an appeal by way ofreview include

a Whether exceptional circumstances exist that wairnnt the admission offu1ther evidence in light of the need for finality in litigation2 The exceptional circutnstances test was stated by the High Court in Fox v Percy 2003 214 CLR 118 at 22 in respect of appeals to the NSW Supreme Coutt It has been adopted in respect of appeals within ACAT in appellate decisions of the Tribunal and the ACT Supreme Court3

b Whether the further evidence is relevant to the grout1ds of appeal in that it will assist the Appeal Tribunal to decide whether there was any eToi in the decision under review4 This may include considering

i whether the evidence relates to facts that existed at the time the decision under appeal was made as evidence that goes to facts that postdate the decision is less likely to be relevant to whether there was any e1Tor in the decision5 and

ii whether the evidence is in the nature of an expert opinion on relevant issues6 a11d

c Whether the paity seeking leave to present the futther evidence had the oppottunity to present that evidence at the hearing at first instance or put another way whether there was any breach of procedural fairness to the patty at

first instance7 and

d Whether the admission of the fu1ther evidence would require even futther evidence still to properly assess the weight to be afforded to it for example

of a breach of procedural fairness but appeared to treat the breach as a relevant consideration

2

where the proposed evidence comprises statements of third parties and its admission may require crossexamination of the makers of those statements8

IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY CIVIL AND ADMINISTRATIVE TRIBUNAL

Wendell Charles Nesmith

Appellant and

ACT Chief Psychiatrist

Respondent

RESPONDENTS SUBMISSIONS

1 The ACT Chief Psychiatrist Respondent seeks orders that the appeal be dismissed and the Tribunals decision of2 August 2018 be confirmed

Background

2 On 2 August 2018 the Tribunal the Original Tribunal made a Psychiatric Treatment Order PTO in relation to the Appellant for a period of 6 months following hearings on 12 July 2018 and 2 August 20181

3 The Tribunals power to make a PTO is set out ins 58 of the Mental Health Act 2015

Mental Health Act as follows

58 Psychiatric treatment order

I This section applies to

a a person assessed under an assessment order or

b a person in relation to whom an application for a mental health order has been made

under part 52 or

c a person in relation to whom an application for a forensic mental health order has been made under division 712 or

d a person required by a court to submit to the jurisdiction of the ACAT nuder the Crimes Act part 13 or the Crimes Act 1914 Cwlth patt IB

2 The ACAT may make a psychiatric treatment order in relation to the person if

a the person has a mental illness and

b eithe1

i the person does not have decisionmaking capacity to consent to the treatment care or

support and refuses to receive the heatment care or support or

ii the person has decisionmaking capacity to consent to the treatment care or support

but refuses to consent and

c the ACAT believes on reasonable grounds that because of the mental illness the

person

i is doing or is likely to do serious harm to themself or someone else or

ii is suffering or is likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration and

1 The Application for a PTO in respect of the Appellant MH 1082012 first came before the Tribunal prior to 12 July 20 I8 but was adjourned to that date so the Appellant could be present Transcript 12 July 2018

pp 34

d in relation to a person mentioned in paragraph b iithe ACAT is satisfied that the harm or deterioration or likely harm or deterioration mentioned in paragraph c is of such a serious nature that it outweighs the persons right to refuse to consent and

e the ACAT is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or support is likelyto

i reduce the harm or deterioration or the likelihood of the harm or deterioration mentioned in paragraph c or

ii result in an improvement in the persons psychiatric condition and

f if an application has been made for a forensic mental health orderthe ACAT is satisfied that a psychiatric treatment order should be made instead and

g the ACAT is satisfied that the treatment care or supp01t to be provided under the psychiatric treatment order cannot be adequately provided in another way that would involve less restriction of the freedom of choice and movement of the person

4 The Appellant is a person in respect of whom a PTO may be made under s 581b The findings of the Original Tribunal as set out in its Statement dated 2 August 2018 match closely the te1ms of s 582 of the Mental Health Act In particular the Original Tribunal found that

the Appellant has a mental illness

the Appellant does not have decisionmalcing capacity to consent to the treatment care or support proposed for him

the Appellant refused the treatment proposed for him

because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with treatment The Tribunal considers his cunent compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment Statement aiv

there are reasonable grounds to believe that the Appellant because of his mental illness

o is likely to do serious haim to himself as a result of misadventure or selfneglect when unwell and

o is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

psychiatric treatment care or support is likely to reduce the likelihood ofhaim or deterioration and is likely to result in an improvement of the Appellants psychiatric condition and

the treatment proposed under the PTO could not be adequately provided in another way that would involve less restriction of the Appellants freedom of choice and movement

5 The Original Tribunals decision was made by majority The Psychiatrist Member was of the view that a PTO should not be made

6 The documentary evidence before the Original Tribunal comprised

the application for a PTO by Dr Emma Glanville Consultant Psychiatrist as delegate or nominee of the Chief Psychiatrist dated 19 June 2018 and

records obtained from the Chief Psychiatrist from mental health services in Victoria Ballarat and QLD Caims in respect of the Appellants prior admissions in those jurisdictions

the Appellant

Facts

8 In summary the evidence before the Tribunal established the following facts

9 The Appellant moved to Australia from the US as a teenager In around 2010 after his marriage ended he returned to the US for some time2

10 The Appellant moved back to Australia in 2011 On 21 June 2011 he presented to Ballarat Health Services following a refe1Tal from a GP to whom he had disclosed a specific plan to commit suicide on his birthday on 27 June 2011 He was homeless and living in the bush He had not eaten for 6 days upon his arrival in Ballarat in around MayJune 2011 He reported previous psychiatric admission in WA although the details are unclear3 He was voluntarily admitted to the Adult Acute Unit in Ballarat on the basis that he had a significant delusional disorder with schizotypal personality issues4

11 The Appellant was discharged from hospital in Ballarat on 26 June 2011 and subsequently seen as anoutpatient until his case was closed on 31 August 2011 Around that time he moved to Pe1th to reside with friends and he was refened to a local mental health service tltere Upon discharge his treating clinician in Ballarat stated that the Appellant had poor insight and did not agree with the diagnosis of schizophrenia5 He was rated as at moderate risk of accidental or deliberate selfharm and low risk ofhaim to others but vulnerable to harm from others He was assessed as being at high risk of noncompliance with treatment6

12 On 28 April 2012 following a refe1Tal from a GP who believed he had schizotypal personality disorder the Appellant was involuntarily admitted to the adult mental health unit at The Canbe1Ta Hospital TCH He was discharged on 5 May 2012 A PTO was not made as he was not floridly psychotic and he subsequently lost contact with services7

13 In 2013 the Appellant was briefly placed on an emergency detention order after he presented at TCH with grandiose and disordered thoughts and requiring surgical intervention because he had inserted a speaker wire into his penis He was discharged within several days as he presented as more settled with no evidence of psychosis He subsequently lost contact with services8

14 In around 2013 the Appellant spent a week in prison in Grafton on his account after he tried to mn for prime minister and the government didnt lilce it9 The Appellant was admitted to psychiatric care in Lismore in 201310 or 201411

15 On 12 April 2016 the Appellant was admitted to the Cairns Mental Health Unit in a floridly psychotic state after he had made sexually inappropriate comments about young girls at a caravan park stating that he wanted to many a virgin12 He was made the subject of an involuntary treatment order He was discharged on 6 May 2016 and seen as an outpatient He willingly engaged with mental health services and was compliant with his medication after discharge On 16 June 2016 the Involuntary Treatment Order was revoked13 He was last seen on 5 July 2016 at which time he reported plans to return to the US14

17 On 4 July 2018 the Appellant was admitted to the Adult Mental Health Unit at TCH under an emergency assessment order after displaying highly agitated and aggressive behaviours towards staff at a Centrelinlc office which had resulted in police being called20 On his admission he was agitated aggressive manic and highly labile and he had intense very wellsystemised delusional beliefs21 He initially Iefused medication but was given intramuscular antipsychotics and subsequently agreed to talce an injection of Olanzapine His presentation was much improved by the first hearing before the Original Tribunal on 12 July 201822 On 17 July 2018 the Appellant was discharged from TCH

Appellants grounds of appeal

that the Appellant was refusing treatment s 582biiGround 1 andor

that the Appellant was a serious risk to himself or others or that he was at risk of deterioration s 582ci and iiGround 2

Respondents submissions on admission of new evidence
