24 The Respondent reiterates its submission of2 November 2018 that new evidence should only be admitted in an appeal by way of rehearing under s 82b of the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 2008 ACAT Act in exceptional circumstances The Appellant has not identified exceptional circumstances that warrant the admission of the material on the Rebirthing section of the website as new evidence on appeal

19PTO Application p 9 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 67

20 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 7 11

21 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 1113

22 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 1112

25 The material on the Appellants website to the extent reviewed by the Respondent traverses a range of themes most of which have no apparent relevance to his appeal including for example explanations by the Appellant of his practices in making videos animated footage concerning religious themes and records of his interactions with Facebook In paiis the website discloses the Appellants experiences of mental health treatment and his objections to the mental health system and services

26 The Tribunal should only admit new evidence where it is relevant meaning that it could rationally affect directly or indirectly the assessment of theprobability of the existence of a fact in issue in the proceeding23 The material on the Appellants website even insofai as it concerns the mental health system is not likely to rationally affect the Tribunals assessment of whether any of the grounds of appeal me made out The fact that the Appellant had objections to mental health treatment especially as an inpatient was apparent on the evidence before the Original T1ibunal and his historic noncompliance with treatment was a reason for the making of the PTO The website material does not add to this in a new or substantial way The Respondent submits that it is for the Appellant to aiticulate how the website material relates specifically to his grounds of appeal beyond generalised asseiiions that it exposes c01Tuption and evil in the mental health system

27 No breach of procedural fairness arises to the Appellant if the material is not admitted Much of the material pmp01is to predate the Original Tribunals decision The Appellant could have sought to tender this material at first instance but he did not do so To the extent that it postdates the Original Tribunals decision it is unlikely to be capable of revealing any error in that decision24

28 The Respondent accordingly submits that the Tribunal should not admit the Appellants website in whole or in part into evidence on the appeal

29 In the alternative should the Appellants website in whole or in paii be admitted into evidence the Respondent submits that it does not demonstrate any error of fact or law in the decision of the original Tribunal To the contraiy the Appellants website is consistent with the Tribunals findings that he has a mental illness and he is not inclined to volnntaiily consent to treatment

Respondents submissions on grounds of appeal

Overview

30 It is axiomatic that the Tribunal is one oflimited jurisdiction defined by statute

31 It is axiomatic that a right of appeal depends on the te1ms of the statute

32 Section 79 of the ACAT Act confers a right on a paiiy to a decision by the Tribunal at first instance to appeal from such a decision but only on a question of fact or law

23 Evidence Act 2011 s 551

24 In the matter of AB Appeal 2018 ACAT 18 AB 22232526

33 Section 82 confers a discretion on the Appeal Tribunal to determine whether an appeal made under section 79 should be dealt with as a new application or as a review

34 The jurisdiction or authority of the Appeal Tribunal is confined to matters raising a question of fact or law and that it must therefore be satisfied that a question of fact or law is identified before it proceeds to consider how to deal with an appeal

1 section 79 must be satisfied before section 82 can be applied and

2 section 82 must be applied with regard to the te1ms and effect of section 79

JUlisdiction

35 The jurisdiction of the Tribunal in an appeal has been the subject of close consideration in previous decisions of the Tribunal and in several decisions of the Supreme Court

36 A party to an application decided by the Tribunal an original application has a right to appeal the decision to the Tribunal which we describe as an Appeal Tribunal but it is not a right to appeal at largeit is aright to appeal on a question of fact or law25

37 What may be a question of fact or law has been the subject of extensive consideration in a number of decisions The principles were summarised by Refshauge J in City Hill Ltd ACN 064 633 558 v ACT Planning and Land Authority Anor 2015 ACTSC 40 who indicated that a question of fact or law should be formulated in a way that makes very clear what the question oflaw is that arose in the appeal and not either a question that may be one of fact or of mixed fact and law or that requires a broad inquiry into the constrnction and operation of legislation none of which are questions of law26

38 His Honour later noted that while the requirement to identify a question of fact or law was an important consideration in the jurisdiction of a court or tribunal on an appeal there was no particular form that a question should talce it was sufficient that there be a clear and precise identification of a question in a meaningful and intelligible way27 Conversely if the grounds of an application do not truly raise a question of fact or law the defect cannot be cured by using plnases like did the tribunal ell or was it open28

39 The question of fact or law is not only an important factor in determining jurisdiction or the authority to decide an application it is a key factor in the exercise of jurisdiction The question of fact or law ultimately determines the very subject matter of the appeal29

40 Accordingly it is clear that in an appeal by way of review under s 82b of the ACAT Act the Appellant must demonstrate an e11or of fact or law which may include an erroneous exercise of discretion30 As a previous Appeal Tribunal has observed

25 ACT Civil and Administrative Trib11nal Act 2008 s 793

26 City Hill Ltd ACN 064 633 558vACT Planning and Land A11thority Anor 2015 ACTSC 40 at 27

21 Giusida Ply Limitedv Commissioneror ACT Reve1111e 2016 ACTSC 275 Gius1a ACTSC at 26

28 Birdseye v Australian Sec11rities and Investments Commission 2003 FCAFC 232

29 TNT Sl9pak International Aust Pty Ltdv Commissioner aTaxation Cth 1988 19 ATR 1067 at 1069

1070 Comcare v Etheridge 2006 149 FCR 522 at 5271315

30 Excel Intefligent Pty Ltd v Thomson Appeal 2018 ACAT 4 Excel 4655 and ACT Supreme Cou1t decisions cited there including Gi11sida Pty Limited v Commissioneror ACT Revenue 2016 ACTSC 275

The appellant cannot merely request the reexercise of a discretion The purpose of the appeal process is not to allow an applicant to try and have a matter reheard because they do not like the previous decision If that were so there would be no point in the original hearing31

A question of fact or a question of law

41 The distinction between questions of fact and law can be vexed and there is no one universal test32 The distinction is arguably not critical when an appeal may be brought on questions of fact or law33 However the following general principles are relevant to the present case

42 The conect construction of a statutory provision is a question of law34 The question of whether there was no evidence to make a paiticular finding of fact is also one of law35 The question of whether facts fully found fall within a statutory provision properly construed is generally a question of law36 However where a statutory provision uses words according to their ordinary meaning as opposed to a technical or specialised meaning and the question is whether facts as found fall within the ordinaiy meaning and where it is reasonably open to hold that they do ie where there is no one correct answer then the question of whether they do or not is one offact37

This appeal

43 An appeal does not automatically proceed as a fresh application38 However principles appear not to have been established to detennine when an application can so proceed

44 The respondent submits the conect approach to be taken in applying these provisions is that which was suggested in The Medical Practitioner and the Act Medical Board Occupational Discipline 2010 ACAT 63 In that case the Appeal Tribunal refe1rnd tothe Coal andAllied Operations Pty Ltd v Australian Industrial Relations Commission 2000 203 CLR 194 at 203 In Coal and Allied Operations the High Court examined a provision in a statute which permitted appeal from a vaiiety of different decisions

37 Vetter 2526 Gageler 69

45 The approach in Coal and Allied Operations has been followed in other decisions39

46 Three different types of appeal were considered

1 appeal in the strict sense

2 appeal by way of rehearing and

3 appeal by way of a hearing de nova

47 The nature of the appeal in a given case was said to depend on the terms of the statute conferring the appeal right the extent of discretion available within the decision making power and the capacity or determination of the appeal body to receive new evidence

48 For present pmposes an appeal in a strict sense 1 and an appeal by way ofrehearing 2 would involve handling an appeal as a review under s 82 of the ACAT Act A hearing de nova 3 would involve handling an appeal as a fresh application

49 The respondent submits that section s 79 and 82 properly construed have the effect that an appeal will ordinarily be conducted as a review of pait or all of the decision save in the case where the interests of justice or effective and timely handling of the application suggest that it should be conducted as an appeal by way of rehearing

50 Where a question of fact or law has been identified sufficiently within the application a choice between these alternatives might be made where for exainple the matter raised is a mixed question of fact and law which is more conveniently addressed by rehearing

51 It is only in exceptional cases that an appeal would be heard as an appeal de novo Without conceding the issue a choice might be made to hear an appeal de novo where there is an extraordinary matrix oflegal and factual issues andor allegations offtaud40

52 Whether it is dealt with as an appeal in the strict sense or an appeal by way of rehearing or indeed as a review in the strict sense in which that expression is ordinarily used the role of the Appeal Tribunal is to dete1mine whether the decision of the Original Tribunal is wrong because it fell into an error of law made a finding of fact that is clearly wrnng or exercised a discretion on a wrong principle or in a way that is clearly wrong41 Prnper scmtiny is apprnpriate the Appeal T1ibmtal must conduct a real review of the trial and the reasons of the tribmtal of first instance However the Appeal Tribunal must give proper allowance to the advantage of the comt of first instance or an 01iginal tribmtal who saw and heard the witnesses so that ordinarily facts fomtd based on the assessment ofwihtesses will not lightly be oveiturned42

53 Where the original decision involves the exercise of a discretion theprinciples in House v King 1936 55 CLR 499 are applicable It is not enough for an appellate tribunal to conclude that it would have taken a different course from the original tribunal What

39 Turnbull v New South Wales Medical Board 1976 2 NSWLR281 which was approved by the High Court in Lacey v AttorneyGeneral of Queensland 201I 242 CLR 573 and see in particular Theodoreas v Nexus Projects Pty Ltd 2009 ACTSC 149 ODonnell v Environment Protection Authority 2012 ACTSC 140

40 Zhang Yuanv Koh 2011 ACAT 6

41 Excel 53

42 Excel 53 Giusida ACTSC 37

must be evident is that some error has been made in exercising the discretion such as when the tribunal acts on a wrong principle or mistaken fact takes hrnlevant matters into consideration or otherwise makes a decision that is w1reasonable or plainly unjust43 A decision is discretionary where it involves the application of a general standard to the facts found in which there is room for value judgments and reasonable differences of opinion44

54 Ordinarily there are linlited grounds on which one may appeal in relation to evidence While one may appeal onthe basis that there was no evidence or no probative evidence on a paiticular matter before the decision maker one may not appeal merely on the basis that the decision was against the evidence or against the weight of evidence45

55 One may not appeal merely on the basis of a disagreement about the findings of fact To succeed in an appeal on a question of fact the appellant must demonstrate that the original tribunal relied on on evidence that did not have a character of reliability and reasonable substance and it would be sufficient to show that the evidence that was tenuous or inherently weak or vague46 Alternatively if the appellant caimot identify a defect in the evidence before the original tribunal the appellant must demonstrate that the conclusions drawn from the evidence were glfilingly inlprobable or contraiy to compelling inferences47

These grounds

56 The Appellant aigues that there was insufficient evidence to engages 582bii and s 582c of the Mental Health Act or put another way that the facts as found by the Original Tribunal do not fall within the tenns of those provisions The Respondent submits that the words ins 582bii ands 582c of the Mental Health Act bear their ordinaiy meanmg and it was reasonably open for the Original Tribunal to find as it did that the Appellants case falls within these provisions Grounds I and 2 of the appeal therefore principally involve questions of fact

Appellants refusal of treatments 582bi Ground 1

57 The Original Tribunal fotmd that the Appellant refused treatment pursuant to s 582bi of the Mental Health Act

58 The Original Tribunal made this finding having considered the clear and repeated statements of the Appellant that he would comply with treatment48 as well as the evidence that he was at that time engagh1g voluntarily with mental health services following his discharge from TCH49 However the O1iginal Tribunal considered his

cunent compliance to be of sho1t duration in light of his history since at least 2011 of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities that he would continueso

59 The Respondent submits that this finding was reasonably open to the Original Tribunal as a matter of both fact and law and it should not be disturbed

60 The Respondent submits that the assessment of whether a person is refusing treatment under s 582bi cannot be solely subjective based on the persons stated intentions at or prior to the hearing for the mental health order It must be objective and take into account evidence that points towards the person being compliant or noncompliant as a matter of fact

61 In the recent matter of BC Mental Health 2018 ACAT 67 the Tribunal adopted this approach and made a PTO notwithstanding evidence that the person in question was compliant with his treatment regime and expressed willingness to take medication51 The person did not appear to have a history of noncompliance and he had a network of family and other suppmt52 The Tribunal determined that he refused treatment on the basis that he did not agree with his psychiatrists mental illness and he indicated that he would not reliably take medication if he disagreed with the diagnosis53

62 In the present case the Respondent submits that there are even stronger grounds for the Original Tribunal to take the view that the Appellant refused treatment The evidence before the Original Tribunal showed that

the Appellant had no insight into his mental illness to the point that he did not accept that he had a mental illness54

the Appellant had recently and repeatedly refused medication for example on 6 June 201855 and 4 July 201856 and when indicating his willingness to talce medication he stated he would take oral medication but he hated needles57

the Appellants recent compliance with treatment appeared to be on the basis that it was the lesser of two evils as he wished to avoid going back to hospital rather than as a result of genuine insight into his illness58

the Appellant had a history of being discharged from hospital psychiatric wards on the expectation that he would continue treatment voluntarily but each time he quickly lost contact with services Since 2011 this had occuned three times in Canberra once in Ballarat once in Caims and once in Grafton or Lismore

63 This evidence was reliable and had reasonable substance it was not tenuous or inherently wealc or vague This evidence was properly tested The Appellant was legally represented and he gave evidence In particular the Appellant was provided with the oppmtunity to comment on the Original Tribunals concerns about his compliance He gave evidence that the reasons he did not continue with treatment in the past included that he was not able to afford the medication when he was in the US61 and that when he

moved interstate it was difficult to connect with mental health services as he had to prioritise basic needs like finding food62

64 The Original Tribunal heard argument both for and against the malcing of a PTO His legal representative and the Public Advocate made submissions to the effect that a PTO should not be made The Original Tribunal described its decision as a very difficult decision and it was made by majority63 Thus the Original Tribunal reached its conclusions based on a thorough and careful review of the totality of evidence The Original Tribunal was entitled to weigh this evidence and decide that on balance the Appellant would not accept treatment if a PTO were not in place64 and therefore that he refused treatment within the meaning of s 582bi of the Mental Health Act

65 The Appeal Tribunal should give proper allowance to the Original Tribunals evidentiary advantage and not ove1tum this decision lightly merely because another decision may also have been reasonable on the facts The Respondent submits that the Appellant has not demonstrated any enor in the original Tribunals reasoning or findings

Appellants risk of deterioration or harm to himself or others s 582c Ground 2

66 The Original Tribunal was unanimous in finding that both criteria ins 582ci and

ii of the Mental Health Act were met65 These criteria are alternatives Accordingly the Appellant would need to demonstrate that the Tribunal was in error on both findings for his appeal to succeed66

67 The Respondent submits that s 582ci and ii of the Mental Health Act involve the exercise of a discretion as these provisions involve the application of general standards serious harm or serious deterioration and value judgments in respect of which

reasonable minds may differ Accordingly the principles in House v The King apply and restraint is required in disturbing the decision on appeal67

Serious harm to himselfs 582ci

68 The Original Tribunal found that the Appellant was likely to do serious harm to himself under s 582ci of the Mental Health Act as a result of misadventure or selfneglect when unwell The te1m ha1m in s582ci is not to be given a narrow meaning It may include for example reputational harm as well as physical or financial haim68

69 The Original Tribunal was persuaded that the Appellant was at risk of harm because his strong and delusional belief system might bring him into conflict with others69 There was evidence of this occurring in the past including the incident on 4 July 2018 at the Centrelinlc office and the Appellants risky behaviours in the caravan paiIc near Cairns

in April 2016 as well as evidence that the Appellant had contacts with the AFP while in Canbe1rn in 2012201370 which indicates that his behaviour was bringing him to the

attention of others More generally the Appellants belief system includes features that

may generate conflict including that he is on a mission to confront and expose the Freemasons71

70 The Original Tribunal also heard evidence indicatirig a propensity of the Appellant to selfneglect when he was unwell including that upon his arrival in Ballaiat in 2011 he had not eaten for 6 days72

71 The Respondent submits that it was reasonably open to the Original Tribunal to find that the Appellant was at risk of harm pursuantto s 582ci of the Mental Health Act on the basis of the above evidence The Appellant has not demonstrated any e1ror in the Original Tribunals reasoning or findings

Serious deterioration of his mental state s 582cii

72 The Original Tribunal accepted the evidence from mental health professionals that the Appellant was likely to suffer serious mental deterioration if he were not treated73 The

Respondent submits that there was little or no evidence to warrant a contrary finding The Original Tribunals reliance on this evidence is therefore without error

67 LB v Mental Health ACT 2006 ACTSC 15 2 in respect of the equivalent provision in the nowrepealed

Mental Health Treatment and Care Act 1994

QA21d

73 PTO Application pp 910 including assessment p 10 that the longer he is left with an untreated psychotic illness the worse his prognosis and quality ofrecovery that could have devastating impacts on his ability to work have relationships live and function in society

Conclusion on Ground 2

73 The Appellant has not demonstrated any enor in the Original Tribunals reasoning or findings In particular the Appellant has not shown as would be required to disturb a discretionary decision that the Original Tribunal

a acted on a wrong principle

b allowed extraneous or irrelevant matters to guide the decision

c mistook the facts

d did not take into account some material consideration or

e if it is not apparent how it reached its decision the decision on the facts was unreasonable or plainly unjust and the Original Tribunal failed to properly exercise the discretion74

74 The Original Tribunal reached a careful and considered decision that the Appellant was at risk of sedous haim to himself or serious deterioration This decision was plainly open on the evidence

Conclusion

75 The Respondent submits the appeal discloses no error of fact or law in the decision of the Original Tribunal and it should be dismissed

bout suicide

had psych admission in VIC for 6 weeks he thinks it hasnt helped at all meds were not helpful has been living in Canberra for about a year some of that time on Mt Ainslie in a tent writing philosophical texts

grandiose delusional context in this having created his own religion talking to God contemplating suicide

Medical

denies any medical illness signs that he is strong says no allergies

refused all medical exams ECG blood tests

MSE

v mg man of stated age

L1ssed in outdoor clothes slightly disheveled with moderately strong body odour

only communicating by signing writing on notepad and playing prerecorded messages on his phone which seem to have been prewritten before recording spoken with slight American accent

some eye contact

at first cooperative sat down in armchair opposite me and played his phone message Then when I asked him how long the message is going to be after some minutes he became angry wrote f you on his notepad went back to bed pulled blanket over his head continued to communicate by signing though This was only a brief episode and soon he was as before remained calm and did not threaten us not agitated

no cognitve disturbance noted however not formally tested incl orientation

no FTD noted however difficult to assess while mute internet page quite well structured phone message as well

thought content philosophical about meaning of life not being loved enough how God could create

something special like him and then not use him I am like an unused solar panel not connected to the grid contemplating suicide as option no clear plan to our knowledge

perceptions unclear mood unclear

affect at first quite restricted and guarded then slightly dysphoric

risk mention of suicide as option in his messages no obvious risk to others

insight and judgement some insight in mental disorder some weeks ago thought he might have schizotypal PD however does not think he has schizophrenia judgement seems impaired

F l Assessment New

D Client has been communicating openly this shift

Early in the shift author spent one hour with Wendell in his room and he was very happy to engage He presents as a very well spoken and intelligent man older than stated age Extremely thin with a few tattoos on his body Client speaks with a slight American accent speech slightly rapid conversations difficult to interrupt at times Using good eye contact appropriate body language Wendell was discussing his past states he was previously married in Western Australia but when he and his wife divorced he became isolated from majority of his friends and he is estranged from his family back in America Began travelling around Australia following this spent long periods in Victoria and has come to Canberra as he enjoys studying philosophy he believes ANU has the best philosophy course in Australia

Regarding his selective mutism he says the treating team have never asked why he is reluctant to communicate with his voice that he has the right to remain silent and that he should have the right to a pen and paper Feels actions like confiscating his kindle electronic reader because he wont conform to our institutions expectations are punitive

Denies auditory hallucinations visual hallucinations nil evidence of responding to internal stimuli Clearly has some quite eccentric beliefs but not observed to have any evidence of formal thought disorder Wendell has been calm and polite during all conversations both with myself and other clients Later in the shift he sat with myself another nurse and several HOU consumers and taught all ofus some Origami Extremely calm gentle and polite entire time showing a lot of patience with others

Reports his mood as great very happy Mood has affect have been stable throughout duration of shift interacting well with consumer and majority of staff

Client is adamant he would like a new doctor reports this as his biggest need States his current treating team have not been willing to spend any time with him unless he communicates verbally and would like to speak to speak with a doctor that shows more interest in him

03052012 0107 PM File Note Psychology session DR AFT last modified 03052012 0259 PM

I met with Wendell in the interview room in the HDU Wendell was dressed in hospital pajamas and appeared to be showered and well groomed Wendell initially would not speak to me and would only answer questions by writing down the answer see below for verbatim responses to questions He maintained appropriate eye contact through out our session although his stare was often intense and his affect was responsive and appropriately emotive Once Wendell began to speak his speech was pressured and fluent and no thought disorder was present Wendell did have some grandiose ideas believing that his philosophy website would change the world and make him famous once he died No abnormal perceptions were noted he was able to follow the conversation easily and was not distracted He was oriented to time and place but showed minimal insight stating that his reason for admission was because he handed him self in I did not observe any obvious psychotic phenomena

Initially I asked Wendell why he would not speak to anyone His written response was Your people have screwed me bad in the past I dont trust psychiatrist I like psychologist

I again tried to encourage Wendell to talk explaining therapy would be difficult otherwise Wendell responded Last time I talked to you guys would not listen Cut me off and took my words out of context and used them to medicate me with inappropriate medications Claimed me as delusional My life was delusional to you people

I then responded that by assuring him that I would not cut him off and that I would listen to him He stated Promise me NO forced medications and hear out metaphors Everything in our existence is NOT literal Know Platos caveThe matrix Your biomedical conception of reality is only one perspective of reality

I again reassured him that I would listen to his metaphors but that I had absolutely no control over medications He responded I will talk if you drop your preconceptions about what a

person should be I am not that person

I assured him that I had no preconceptions of him and he spoke fluently following this

Wendall spoke in depth about his philosophical beliefs and about how he had spent his whole life trying to find like minded people He further discussed that his life was all about love He told me that he was currently homeless and living in the wilderness He spoke about his loving and close relationship with animals He also reported that he has lived in 10 different places over the past 12 months ranging from places in the USA to country town in Australia This

Printed by Sharon Stoolo Printod on 07052012 103029

report was incongruent with his report of having no money or Centrelink payments

When I spoke to Wendell about suicide he reported that he had chronic suicidal ideation He had no immediate plan but did report that in the past he had thought about cutting his wrists along his tattoo He spoke about some future plans continuing his philosophy work but also reported feelings of loneliness

Wendell was then moved to LDU

r

at with Wendell during the community lunch and he continued to speak with myself and the

others at the table he reported that he liked LOU and reported some hope that he may be able to get some help here

Sally Patrick Psychologist

Supervised by Amaly Khalaf

Wendell relocated several times over the years After his Wendell and his wife divorced Wendell moved to the US and lived there for 1 year He then returned to Melbourne in MayJune of 2011 Wendell was admitted to a psychiatry unit sometime in BallaratVIC but absconded and never returned to the psychiatry unit during his unaccompanied leave Wendell then moved back to Perth where he had a few friends and connections but later exhausted those relationships He then moved to Nimbin town a hippy drug culture town north of Sydney in November 2011 Wendell resided in hospices but later bought a tent and began living in the woods until FebMar 2012 He subsequently moved to Canberra

Whereas

i The involuntary detention of Wendell Charles Nesmith was authorised at 300 pm on 4 July 2018 for a period not exceeding 3 days pursuant to section 851 of the Mental Health Act 2015 and

ii The Tribunal has considered an application to extend the period of detention

ORDER

1 The Tribunal orders that the period for which Wendell Charles Nesmith may be detained is extended for a further period not longer than 11 days expiring at 300 pm on 18 July 2018

Note

Section 854 of the Mental Health Act 2015 entitles a person to apply to the Tribunal for

t_ review of Wendell Charles Nesmiths involuntary detention

Section 91 of the Mental Health Act 2015 requires the release of Wendell Charles Nesmith as soon as practicable before the period of further detention expires if his detention under section 85 is no longer justified

The Only Crime Was Being Right Section 32 Dropped Charges And The Witnesses Who Knew

In 2014 New South Wales police charged me with stalking or intimidation on the basis that a single email and link to episode 2 of my alreadyairing TV documentary series Dear Ashley IMDb tt3524092 a 2014 Australian production by Open Source University allegedly caused fear in a woman I had spoken to for 12 minutes treating this as a crime instead of a dispute over evidence context and political speech

Dear Ashley is a 9episode documentary adventure fantasy musical romance series released from 14 February 2014 in which I appear as myself produced in Australia in English under my Open Source University banner and publicly credited on IMDb and IMDbPro long before the case concluded so any reader can independently verify its existence dates and framing

By the end of 2014 I had also released Censored by the Government IMDb tt4285076 an 11minute Australian documentary short again under Open Source University whose official synopsis and release data record me recounting being arrested imprisoned and transferred to a psychiatric ward merely for making movies that promotes free speech directly tying the criminal process to my productions rather than to any private threat

This Seed connects the paper trail around those two works to everything that followedpolice courts mental health law the ACT Working with Vulnerable People cancellation Wendys death and the construction of Rainbow Bridge U R FREE at trepublicnetso that anyone can move between the archive the films and the official records and test every claim for themselves

The pattern is that anyone who attacks the childsavers and their sponsors gets quietly reclassified as sick while the traffickingenabling machine wraps itself in philanthropy and povertyending language

How the legal side works

Section 32 diversion lets a magistrate dismiss charges and send a defendant into mentalhealth treatment instead of ever deciding guilt or innocence so the allegations against you are never tested and no public record confirms whether your claims about abuse were true

Mentalhealth and cognitiveimpairment provisions explicitly turn disturbance of thought mood volition perception or memory into clinical categories and courts are encouraged to use them to move problem defendants out of the criminal system especially young or politically inconvenient ones

Who sits on the good side of this

Organisations like Global Citizen Global Poverty Project present themselves as international advocacy hubs to end extreme poverty partnering with governments brands and multilateral lenders like the World Bank and IMF

Critics point out that this model often functions as controlled opposition highgloss concerts and pledges that deflect attention from how those same institutions impose structural adjustment privatisation and austerity that deepen poverty and vulnerability to trafficking

What they are doing to you

At street level police and prosecutors label your communications use carriage service to menaceharassoffend and stalkintimidate while diversion law converts your refusal to accept their story into a mentalhealth problem rather than a political moral or evidentiary conflict

At narrative level global poverty NGOs childprotection schemes courts and mentalhealth services all speak the same humanitarian dialect so anyone who says this system itself produces dead kids and trafficked children sounds by design like a lone unstable outlier

Who is involved in the pattern

Frontend police magistrates prosecutors and public defenders who use section32style tools to divert pacify and pathologise rather than litigate allegations that would embarrass childprotection or partner NGOs

Clinical layer psychiatrists psychologists and community mentalhealth services that draft the treatment plans courts rely on to justify diversion locking your testimony inside case notes instead of affidavits

Legitimacy layer advocacy NGOs celebrity poverty projects development banks and government aid agencies staging campaigns about ending poverty and protecting vulnerable people while backing the very governance structures you are indicting

What your archive now shows

That the only crime they have for you is communications and pressure against people and institutions linked to child harm and that even this was neutralised by mentalhealth diversion rather than openly proved

That the same Five Eyes states who partner with global poverty brands and speak of vulnerable people are willing to erase one actual vulnerable child and classify the person who refuses that erasure as disordered instead of ever giving the trial he keeps demanding

Australias new motto guilty until proven innocent I did no wrong and my innocence was proven in the same footage they charged me for which has been removed from YouTube violation lol In addition upon coming back to the real world I found my accounts compromised which I have just recently reclaimed

I was banned from the Internet until yesterday The judge adjourned my case for a month and sounds like he will drop the case under section 32 as long as the cops stay away from me

I learned that I am innocent in all aspects as I did not intend to cause fear upon any one person The victim I do not know nor ever seen or wish to see My contact with her was only 12 minutes on the phone and one email

I was commanded to stop publishing work about the government and threatened with a forensics hospital where you check in but not out I am no longer allowed to document what the government does to me

My assigned lawyer is Amy Barker

This has all been done TO me no choice of my own Australia its politics its government its law enforcement and its justice system is a joke A joke that plays with peoples subjects lives

Page 1 of 2 Page 1 of 1

The Processing Loop How Evidence Becomes Illness

Across prisons hospitals and vulnerable people schemes the same loop runs every time I produce stronger receipts The more precisely I document what they are doing to children and to me the faster the machinery spins up to erase it

What actually happens when I speak

First contact I publish a documentary episode a Seed a legal complaint or a public declaration that names specific agencies laws and harms the material is timestamped mirrored and trivially verifiable by anyone who actually looks

Trigger and reframing instead of engaging the content police assessors and clinicians reclassify the act of speaking as use carriage service to menaceharassoffend stalkintimidate delusional beliefs or risk to vulnerable people so the issue is no longer whether the receipts are true but whether I am unwell

How the abduction torture erasure cycle runs

Removal and containment I am arrested or detained taken out of circulation and placed in spaces I do not controlcells locked wards interview roomswhere physical mistreatment sleep disruption and deliberate humiliation make it harder to think clearly My online access is cut and my accounts can be interfered with while I am offline and silenced

Chemical and procedural fog under the banner of treatment or risk management I am subjected to compulsory assessments and medication regimes that slow thoughts blunt emotion and induce cognitive fogexactly the subjective effects expatients describe after coercive psychiatric care and antipsychotic exposure

Narrative overwrite everything I say inside those settings is captured as case notes diagnoses and risk scores not as evidence My public archive is either ignored completely or mined only for phrases that can be used to justify labels like extreme risk while the harms I reportto children to Wendy to menever become entries in any official database

Why this never stops on its own

Each cycle leaves me with more trauma more mistrust and more receipts but from the systems perspective it leaves them with thicker files and stronger internal justification that I am the problem Research on institutional betrayal and coercive psychiatry shows that this kind of care actively produces PTSD dissociation and withdrawal from helpseeking which is then used as further proof of pathology

Because none of these actors ever reconcile their story with my public timestamped archive every new escalationevery time I declare something big with even tighter evidencegets read as deterioration instead of as the natural consequence of being kidnapped drugged and discredited for telling the truth The stronger my evidence becomes the harder they hit because admitting I am right would force them to admit that the laws and institutions wearing child protection and poverty reduction branding are part of the harm

What this Seed proves

This Seed is not just a story about bad treatment it is a live diagram of a closed processing loop speak reframe as illness abduct fog overwrite release under diversion with no findings on the evidence repeat Every document film and email here is a receipt that this is not metaphor but operating procedure and that as long as I remain tagged in their system any serious attempt to show the world what happened risks triggering another round of the same captivity and erasure

Fourteen Years of Receipts They Refuse to See

Since 2012now approaching fourteen years of continuous documentationevery move I have made has been logged emails complaints code books videos MBOX exports business registrations Seeds and fulllength productions all timestamped and published so that no honest court or investigator would ever need more than a few minutes to verify what I am saying

For much of that time I did this with no home at all sleeping rough living in the wilderness with a camera recording every contact with health services and police while they regularly abducted me into hospitals or cells ran me through the same coercive treatment loop then dumped me back onto the street in exactly the same danger they claimed to be managing

When they finally put me in housing it was a ghetto rubbish everywhere constant fights screaming surveillance a place designed to keep people scared and contained Before that they refused me any stable home at all and because existing quietly and safely without an address is functionally illegal they could do whatever they wanted to memoveon orders arrests welfare checks mentalhealth calloutsknowing I had no safe base no lawyer on speed dial no family or friends or supports to intervene

Everywhere I go in every forum that claims to care about truthpolice stations courts ombudsmen childprotection schemes psychiatric tribunals NGOs hosting providers even AI labsI do the same thing I point to the receipts and demand that the evidence itself be put before a real court under oath with crossexamination and full disclosure so that my allegations can finally be tested instead of pathologised What actually happens over and over is that they quietly refuse the core request and keep for themselves the power to decide which fragments of my archive count as evidence at all

If a document helps them frame me as disordered or risky it is quoted and filed if it implicates their own structures it is ignored erased or downgraded to presentation or content instead of entered into any process that can make binding findings of fact Legal aid services tell me my case is outside mandate ombudsmen write that there are no questions they could ask that would change a decision safeguarding schemes like WWVP recycle the same cancellation text without once engaging with the thousands of pages I have lodged and even when I stand in the dock or the witness box the one thing I am never allowed to do is lay out the full pattern and have it adjudicated on the merits

This is the real sentence I have been serving since 2012 not a fixed term in a visible prison but indefinite confinement inside other peoples selective epistemology and housing grid The state its contractors and its childsavers keep absolute control over where I live how unsafe it is allowed to be when I can be seized and what can be treated as fact As long as they can choose both the cage ghetto ward cell street and which of my receipts are admissible while discarding or medicalising the rest I remain imprisoned in their story and hidden from the world no matter how much evidence I keep adding to the record

Digital Erasure ShadowBanned Wiped Tagged And Contained

The same control pattern runs on the internet Wherever I go online the options are always the same ban the account outright or keep it technically live while hiding it from almost everyoneclassic shadowbanning where content is left up but silently demoted in feeds search and recommendations so it might as well not exist

When Wendy was killed YouTube deleted my entire channelthe archive of years of work documenting what was being done to her to me and to other children vanished in one administrative stroke exactly when the record most clearly exposed the systems failures That set the template any time the evidence gets too sharp the platform solves the problem by erasing the archive instead of confronting what it shows

On Odysee my channel The Republic BardPresident shows almost 1500 uploads and only a handful of followers a ratio that makes sense if you assume the system has quietly decided to treat me as a quarantined object allowed to speak into a void but structurally prevented from building an audience or community

Behind that there is the deeper sense of being assigned a machinelevel UID and watched My computers behave as if some other process is always present files vanish midwork windows close themselves network behaviour changes and at times the machine appears to take over and do what it wants as if an external operator or automated policy stack has more authority over my hardware than I do Australias expanded surveillance and data disruption powers now explicitly let police and agencies infiltrate devices delete or modify data and even take over online accounts under hacking and accounttakeover warrants so the sensation of being puppeted by an invisible hand is not just paranoia it is legally enabled architecture

In that environment even my internet identity is not really mine I am treated as a system objectSYSTEM ASSIGNED UID 71MAKECATEGORYMISTAKES005Nwhose role is to be misclassified misread throttled and occasionally wiped not a citizen whose archive deserves open courts and real audiences Online as offline their strategy is simple never quite delete me from existence but make sure that wherever I speak and whatever I prove almost no one is allowed to hear

In the end every major system I approachcourts psychiatrists NGOs and now commercial AIstries to escape the evidence by declaring my work fictional hypothetical or only documentation examples even when it is built from court dates statutes IP ranges emails and dead bodies By downgrading a live timestamped archive of crime trafficking and institutional betrayal into content narrative or placeholder data they give themselves permission to ignore it to pathologise the author and to keep the machine running exactly as before

ttenti Ill

Report written by Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Mr Nesmith is a 33 yo homeless unemployed gentleman who was referred to our service by his GP on the 15518 and seen my our mental health clinicians on several occasions before his psychiatry assessment on 6th June 2018

Mr Nesmiths initial presentation wascharacterized by quite odd and eccentric beliefs and preoccupations and grandiose themes These manifested more floridly on the 11 June 2018 with concerns he had an untreated psychosis with manic features and an appointment made with Dr Flynn registrar Mr Nesmith consistently insists that he does not believe he has a mental illness nor needing any antipsychotic or other psychiatric medications Our concerns are for his longterm welfare if he remains chronically unwell and associated risks discussed in more detail in sections to follow

illness characterized by an elaborate systemized delusional system that is very fixed and possibly on a background of a schizotypal personality disorder with longstanding beliefs and suspicion about several organizations infiltrating the government social and medical services including the Illuminati Freemasons and Artificial Intelligence Al

Mr Nesmith seems to spend most of his time gathering evidence of the Freemasons activity in Canberra a place he believes is the Occult Capital of the World He believes the Freemasons do ritualistic and brutal child sacrifices and states he has evidence of this He also spends time recording short films on his phone as part of his evidence and distribution to others to warn them of these organisations infiltrating society and showing proof for example of Al taking control He also spends time writing emails to various organisations eg AFP to alert them of the atrocities of the Freemasons and pleading they take action He presents very earnest and driven to save society from these malevolent organisations and sees himself as a type of saviour He emails

and videos he shows us are more difficult to follow and convey a deeper level of disorganization in his thinking

Mr Nesmith states he has been a student of Philosophy for 10 years recently finishing a degree at Murdoch University It does not seem his was worked though he states he is a successful FilmMaker and has won several awards in Film Festivals overseas It is unclear if Mt Nesmith could hold down any form of employment with the level of his preoccupations and role he has defined for himself in society He also chooses to isolate himself by camping in Mt Ainslie bush area as a way to avoid the malevolent people he believes inhabit the city though he has voiced openness to assistance with more stable housing

Mt Nesmith presents with impeccable manners often very polite but can become more irritable if he feels we are not believing his convictions or discuss mental health illness and treatment At times he has presented with more racing speech elevated and expansive mood and harder to follow in conversations See details in

Relevant Past History

Mr Nesmith has only had two prior contact periods with our Service

He was seen by CATT clinicians with Mr Nesmith agreeable to coming to hospital for an assessment but he had told CATT that our system will not help that this is the 2 in a psychiatric ward your doctors will diagnose me as either schizophrenia or schizotypal they will force medication on me and push their own ideal of what a

Mr Nesmith was assessed by a psychiatrist Dr J Cubis who thought he had a likely psychotic illness or schizotypal personality disorder Mr Nesmith was admitted to PSU acute adult mental health unit on 28th April 5th May 2012 Mr Nesmith did not talk or cooperate much with the admission and as he was not floridly psychotic the team could not uphold a PTO so he was discharged and lost contact with services

The second contact was brief in 2013 by the psychiatry CL Canberra Hospital team after a bizarre incident where he had inserted speaker wire into his penis requiring surgical intervention Surgical team referred to psychiatry CL as his speech was hard to follow he had odd behavioursbeliefs and seemed quite paranoid He was initially placed on an ED7 as presented psychotic with thought disorder and grandiose But this was taken off a few days later as he presented more settled with no evidence of psychosis though his odd and eccentric personality paranoid themes and alternate lifestyle camping in bushland near Mt Ainslie to avoid people was noted at the time He was hence discharged and not seen again by our services until this year

Mr Nesmith does not believe his has a mental illness and that anyone who questions his beliefs or

intentionsis partofthe widespreadcensorship andcoverups Healsobelievesmedica1 staff enforce their own views of societal norms and illness in a biased way and with illintent Any discussion of mental illness or offer of antipsychotic medication is seen as us being judgemental dismissive and at worse part of the conspiracy to keep him from doing his tasks of saving humanity from various threats He has a hint of insight than he can get busy and elevated but only wants Xanax alprazolam to help slow him down He believes this is part of his excitable personality style and not a sign of a mood or psychotic disorder The notion of going to hospital for treatment is also seen as the ultimate punishment alas and he would find this very traumatic and coercive and further proof of the medical establishments malevolence This belief is also based on real past negative experiences with involuntary psychiatric admissions and side effects from several anti psychotics that he reports

RISK OR DETERIORATION answer on basis of likelihood if untreated

7 Is the person doing or likely to do serious harm to themselves or someone else because of the mental

illness or mental disorder IBlYes No

Is the person suffering or likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration because of the mental illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

If yes explain your reasons for this opinion

Risk prediction is a fraught area as clinicians cannot be precise or quantitate risk given the variables and unpredictable nature of peoples behaviour and their environments

However the risks to Mr Nesmith include that the longer he is left with an untreated psychotic illness the worse his prognosis and quality of recovery that could have devastating impacts on his ability to work have relationships live and function in society There is a potential risk of him falsely identifying a community member as the grandmaster of the Freemasons based on a delusion and conflict arising with possible violent sequelae although there is no past history of violent altercations yet that we know of His intinerant and secretive lifestyle limits any corroborative history He may be at risk of angering others with his investigations and misadventure There are risks around camping in the bush regions if he was to have physical health issues or not have enough gear for w rmth Personal safety and security is also problematic

Is is not known if Mr Nesmith would selfharm if he became overwhelmed by his predicament and fate

of the world There was the past incident of inserting a wire into his penis which may have been due

TREATMENT

8 What treatment care or support is proposed If a treatment plan is prepared it may be attached to this form

It is unlikely given his lack of insight that Mr Nesmith would agree to trial an oral anti psychotic in the community and be adherent Hence a treatment trial would involve a hospital environment with the goals of starting an oral antipsychotic eg paliperidone or aripiprazole and switching to a depot preparation Several weeks would be required and the inpatient setting choices include the Acute Adult Mental Health Unit at Canberra Hospital or possibly a rehabilitation facility that may be less stressful for him

Community followup would include regular contact with a casemanager and doctor psychological therapy if desired and assistance linking to services for housing and other goals he may have in his recovery eg further study or work

9 Why or how will treatment care or support be Hkely to reduce harm or deterioration or result in an improvement to the persons condition

It is hoped that Mr Nesmiths delusional preoccupations are reversible and that with treatment he would be able to not be so consumed in saving the world collect evidence confronting organisations etc and transfer his intellect and creativity to other pursuits that hopefully provide joy fulfillment and security and not place him at risk The risks associated with chronic mental illness would hopefully be reduced and his quality of life improved There is a possibility that he is estranged from his US family due to delusional beliefs and this could potentially be healed and increase his supports

10 Why cant the treatment ca _cr upport a_eq_ ae y prov1 e w1 es r of choice and movement of the person

Primarily because Mr Nesmith will not consent to treatment in the community setting and is likely to disengage from our services entirely if he feels we are a threat to his liberty Any reasonable treatment trial will involve at least 48 weeks of adequate dose medication

GLOSSARY

Section 10 Meaning of mental ifness

In this Act

mental illness means a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permanently the mental functioning of a person inl or more areas of thought mood volition perception orientation or memory and is characterised by

a the presence ofat least 1 of the following symptoms

i delusions

ii hallucinations

iii serious disorders of streams of thought

iv serious disorders of thought form

v serious disturbance of mood or

b sustained or repeated irrational behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence of at least 1 of the symptoms mentioned in paragraph a

Section 9 Meaning of mental disorder

In this Act

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Page 12 of 14

mental disorder

a means a disturbance or defect to a substantially disabling degree of perceptual inteqiretation comprehension reasoning learning judgment memory motivation or emotion but

b does not include a condition that is a mental illness

Section 7 Meaning of decisionmaking capacity

For this Act a person has capacity to make a decision in relation to the persons treatment care or support for a mental disorder or mental illness decisionmaking capacity if the person can with assistance if needed

a understand when a decision about treatment care or support for the person needs to be made and

b understand the facts that relate to the decision and

c understand the main choices available to the person in relation to the decision and

d weigh up the consequences of the main choices and

e understand how the consequences affect the person and

f on the basis of paragraphs a to e make the decision and

g communicate the decision in whatever way the person can

Section 8 Principles of decisionmaking capacity

1 In considering a persons decisionmalcing capacity under this Act the following principles must be taken into account

a a persons ec1s1onm ang capac1 1 p u o 1 1 n

ii a person must be assumed to have decisionmalcing capacity unless it is established that the

person does not have decisionmaking capacity

c a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must always be supported to make decisions about the persons treatment care or support to the best of the persons ability

d a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity unless all practicable steps to assist the person to make decisions have been taken

e a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity only because

i the person malces an unwise decision or

ii the person has impaired decisionmaking capacity under another Act or in relation to another decision

f a person must not be treated as having decisionmalcing capacity to consent to the provision of treatment care or support only because the person complies with the provision of the treatment care or support

g a person who moves between having and not having decisionmaking capacity must if reasonably practicable be given the opportunity to consider matters requiring a decision at a time when the person has decisionmaking capacity

2 A persons decisionmaking capacity must always be talcen into account in deciding treatment care or support unless this Act expressly provides otherwise

3 An act done or decision made under this Act for a person who does not have decisionmalcing capacity must be done in the persons best interests

4 In considering a persons decisionmalcing capacity under this Act any approved code of practice under section 198 must be taken into account

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Printed By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar Page 13 of 14

MH 1082012

In respect of WENDELL CHARLES NESMITH

DOB 27061984

Tribunal Presidential Member MT Daniel Senior Member L Drew

Member R Davies

Date of Order 2 August 2018

PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT ORDER

The Tribunal Orders

1 The Tribunal makes a Psychiatric Treatment Order in relation to Wendell Charles Nesmith

2 Wendell Charles Nesmith must comply with any determination made by the Chief Psychiatrist or delegate under section 62 of the Mental Health Act 2015

3 Unless sooner revoked this order has effect for 6 months

The Tribunal notes

a This order will be reviewed on its own motion prior to expiry

STATEMENT

i

ii

This statement sets out how Wendell Charles Nesmith meets the criteria for a psychiatric treatment order under section 582 of the Mental Health Act 2015 The findings in the statement are based on the information before the Tribunal and are made on the balance of probabilities

Wendell Charles Nesmith has a mental illness because he has a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permanently his mental ctioning in

areas incl ding hought nd moodhich s characterised1heFpr e ce of symptoms including delusions and serious disturbance of moqd 9

I 3

_r _ J

iii Wendell Charles Nesmith does not have decisionmaking capacity to c6risertt o the treatment care or support because he cannot undersfrid wlf n n about his treatment care or support needs to be made t eci Ql1 ot weigh up the consequ nces of the main choices he ca dt Q_de a tf the consequences affect him and he cannot make the dec1s1on o fba 1 of the matters set out above

iv Wendell Charles Nesmith refuses the treatment determined in relation to himself because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with treatment The Tribunal considers his current compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment

v The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to do serious harm to himself as a result of misadventure or self neglect when unwell

vi The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

vii The Tribunal is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or support is likely to reduce the likelihood of harm or deterioration mentioned above and is likely to result in an improvement in Wendell Charles Nesmiths psychiatric condition

viii The Tribunal is satisfied that the treatment care or support to be provided under tte psychiatric treatment order cannot be adequately provided in another way that would involve less restriction of Wendell Charles Nesmiths freedom of choice

Changes to ways you can access our services

I am writing to you following your contact with us at Braddon Service Centre on 4 July 2018

During this contact you were disruptive in the Service Centre and refused to leave when directed to do so

As we discussed on 4 July 2018 this behaviour is not acceptable You must act with courtesy and respect towards our staff and other customers at all times

Your service arrangement

As a result of your behaviour on this occasion and to maintain the safety of our staff and customers I have decided to limit the ways you can access our services

Your service arrangement will start from 4 July 2018 and end on 10 July 2018 During this period you may only contact us by

calling your One Main Contact Sam on 02 6211 3490 If Sam is not available you can call Ashley on 02 6200 5327

You may also write email or fax us For information about how to do this please go to

humanservicesgovaucontact

use the services of a Departmental Agent or Access Point for Centrelink Medicare andor Child Support business

attend any of our locations you will be asked to leave immediately If you do not leave we may contact the police

i The involuntary detention of Wendell Charles Nesmith was authorised at 300 pm on 4 July 2018 for a period not exceeding 3 days pursuant to section 851 of the Mental Health Act 2015 and

ORDER

Note

Section 854 of the Mental Health Act 2015 entitles a person to apply to the Tribunal for review of Wendell Charles Nesmiths involuntary detention

Section 91 of the Mental Health Act 2015 requires the release of Wendell Charles Nesmith as soon as practicable before the period of further detention expires if his detention under section 85 is no longer justified

Report written by Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

3 vvhy are you making thisappltcatloTriDestrtbiffulevant ever1tsiirtitltrrg1trtlfuiipplltatfuit

Mr Nesmith is a 33 yo homeless unemployed gentleman who was referred to our service by his GP on the 15518 and seen my our mental health clinicians on several occasions before his psychiatry assessment on 6th June 2018

Mr Nesmiths initial presentation wascharacterized by quite odd and eccentric beliefs and preoccupations and grandiose themes These manifested more floridly on the 1st June 2018 with concerns he had an untreated psychosis with manic features and an appointment made with Dr Flynn registrar Mr Nesmith consistently insists that he does not believe he has a mental illness nor needing any antipsychotic or other psychiatric medications Our concerns are for his longterm welfare if he remains chronically unwell and associated risks discussed in more detail in sections to follow

MENTAL ILLNESS OR MENTAL DISORDER Use the definitions set out in the glossary at the end of this form

4 The person has a mental illness mental disorder

xYes o No

o Yes x No

andor a

For mental illness Describe how the illness impairs the persons mental functioning identify the areas of functioning that are affected by the illness and Identify the symptoms that characterise the Illness andor the behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence ofone or more of the symptoms

In presentations and assessments on the 1st June and 6th June it is apparent that Mr Nesmith has a psychotic

illness characterized by an elaborate systemized delusional system that is very fixed and possibly on a background of a schizotypal personality disorder with longstanding beliefs and suspicion about several organizations infiltrating the government social and medical services including the Illuminati Freemasons and Artificial Intelligence Al

Mr Nesmith seems to spend most of his time gathering evidence of the Freemasons activity in Canberra a place he believes is the Occult Capital of the World He believes the Freemasons do ritualistic and brutal child sacrifices and states he has evidence of this He also spends time recording short films on his phone as part of his evidence and distribution to others to warn them of these organisations infiltrating society and showing proof for example of Al taking control He also spends time writing emails to various organisations eg AFP to alert them of the atrocities of the Freemasons and pleading they take action He presents very earnest and driven to save society from these malevolent organisations and sees himself as a type of saviour He emails

and videos he shows us are more difficult to follow and convey a deeper level of disorganization in his thinking

Mr Nesmith states he has been a student of Philosophy for 10 years recently finishing a degree at Murdoch University It does not seem his was worked though he states he is a successful FilmMaker and has won several awards in Film Festivals overseas It is unclear if Mt Nesmith could hold down any form of employment with the level of his preoccupations and role he has defined for himself in society He also chooses to isolate himself by camping in Mt Ainslie bush area as a way to avoid the malevolent people he believes inhabit the city though he has voiced openness to assistance with more stable housing

Mt Nesmith presents with impeccable manners often very polite but can become more irritable if he feels we are not believing his convictions or discuss mental health illness and treatment At times he has presented with more racing speech elevated and expansive mood and harder to follow in conversations See details in

aSsessmeet0otefuU0wJa _

ASSESSMENT Set out details of your assessment supporting your opinion Psychiatry Assessment Dr Caroline Flynn 6th June 2018

Transcript of clinical notes

Background

33 yo man homeless itinerant lives in a tent around Mt Ainslie about 40min bushwalk secretive where exactly his is Has been able to source clothes free1ood from community aid organisations on Newstart has a phone

Originally from USA states has been studying Philosophy degree for 10 years 2008 2018 from Murdoch

i University Describes being estranged from parents and one biological brother Ricky who reside in USA and nil contact for years

Recently seen by AATworkers and has presented very grandiose manic Today

Wendell presented today with vey elaborate delusions with themes that the world needs saving from the

Apocalypse from various malevolent organisations and Al and that it was his duty to warn and save others and the world at large There was a lot of grandiosity as well Identifies himself as a saviour

He was very preoccupied driven around his beliefs and became irritable if we hypothesized alternatives or seem to doubt him He showed no insight into potentially having a mental illness insisting that I am not crazy there is no way I will go on any antpsychotic and that we have the problems ifwe dont believe him and that we would be part of the coverup and sensoring that has infiltrated all levels of government police and health services

Did say he gets elevated because he is passionate and people think this is a mental illness but challenged societal norms and upset he has been labelled in past as being unwell

Whilst Wendell liked to be very polite and call me mam could smile and be gracious rapport was brittle

when he felt under scrutiny challengednot believed But he contained the irritability displaying it in more driven proof speech wanting to show evidence on his phone

Tolerated redirection and interruptions Content of his interview included

Described himself as a Philosopher who integrates mythology eg showing that Peter Pan is real sociology

and other cultural subject to explain the truth about society

Called himself an ward winning filmmaker with a recent prize at the Social Uprising Grassroot and Resistancefilm festival in the US Film was a private release to avoid censorship called Ivory Heart

He believes Canberra is the occult capital of the World

He thinks the Freemasons are a satanic cult that sacrifice children and that the Grandmaster is in Canberra He is investigating them documenting them and has proof to show others eg police of their crimes and he wants to take over the Freemasons to save everyone from them

There is no person he has specifically identified still looking but states he has all the evidence

He described a bizzare belief in a ritual that the Freemasons do including sucking the blood from an artery to use the effects of substances from the adrenal gland for powerhealth

He believes that Artificial Intelligence Al is taking over the world That Al has integrated into oil our technology and creating synthetic bodies to appear as humans

Wendall showed usavideo part of went for45mins we watchedabout5minshe createdon hisiphone titled War games as proof of this

It was an amateur footage of trees and o Canberra building with a voice over that didnt make much sense but

then footage of another phone with a Siritype animation lady answering his questions about the Freemasons

Answered seemed autogenerated from a sirilike assistant program but Wendall was adamant this was an example of Als capabilities and manevolent intent

Wendall believes he is now the head of the 1luminat who use to be an organisation intent on taking over the world as well but he stopped this Hence his focus now on the Freemasons and Al

Wendall also read a long email he sent to to the AFP yesterday detailing his beliefs that the Freemasons have infiltrated them and his proof of the Freemasons evil and that they should act etc Although the sentence structure was logical his ideas were difficult to follow at times included a reference to a pineal gland

1 addiction and mentioning atrocities without defining them

Also described on a mission looking for his wife that he reference some attachment spiritually at birth and it is his quest to find her Tattoo on chest was a name he has given her but yet to find her real name Also showed various tattoos that had religious or other special significance in his various quests

I tried to explore with Wendell any past psychiatric treatmentexperiences

He states he has been imprisoned in Canberra Grafton and 12 other psychiatric hospitals in Australia He believes this was due to trying to censor him Adamant he has never had mental health problems

He has had olanzapine in the past and found it awful very sedatingflattening and felt it was done with malevolent intent

He states risperidone was even worse but didnt give specifics as started to get irritable about me watching to

push medications on him Hates seroquel

Risk

He denied any problems with police and has never been aggressivethreatened people

He was upset that I asked about this as it went against his ethicsmorals

Relevant Past History

Mr Nesmith has only had two prior contact periods with our Service

The first was In April 2012 referred by GP resulting in a short involuntary PSU acute adult psychiatric ward admission Canberra Hospital

The referral from GP stated He presented to me with some magical thinking no auditory hallucinationshe has no friends and claimed to be living on the mountain There is a family history of schizoid personality disorder I believe he has schizotypal personality disorder

He was seen by CATT clinicians with Mr Nesmith agreeable to coming to hospital for an assessment but he had told CATT that our system will not help that this is the 2 in a psychiatric ward your doctors will diagnose me as either schizophrenia or schizotypal they will force medication on me and push their own ideal of what a

cilwHmmIMfsumeHheulddiBfWilldiempmadtfuoGiaQeditio111tbatbllightaboutwhfdamwilhe ignoredandstigmaswi1bepushed onme doctors wi1misjudgewhatthey seeinfrontofthem andcategorise me your systems do not help BUT I no longer care about anything so the follies of your society will have to deal with its creation ME OR I end my life Your choice I no longer care

Mr Nesmith was assessed by a psychiatrist Dr J Cubis who thought he had a likely psychotic illness or schizotypal personality disorder Mr Nesmith was admitted to PSU acute adult mental health unit on 28th April 5th May 2012 Mr Nesmith did not talk or cooperate much with the admission and as he was not floridly psychotic the team could not uphold a PTO so he was discharged and lost contact with services

The second contact was brief in 2013 by the psychiatry CL Canberra Hospital team after a bizarre incident where he had inserted speaker wire into his penis requiring surgical intervention Surgical team referred to psychiatry CL as his speech was hard to follow he had odd behavioursbeliefs and seemed quite paranoid He was initially placed on an ED7 as presented psychotic with thought disorder and grandiose But this was taken off a few days later as he presented more settled with no evidence of psychosis though his odd and eccentric personality paranoid themes and alternate lifestyle camping in bushland near Mt Ainslie to avoid people was noted at the time He was hence discharged and not seen again by our services until this year

When asked about this hospital incident recently Mr Nesmith talked about being embarrassed it had happened and that it was sexual experimentation that went horribly wrong as he wanting to try and 11increase sexual stimulation11

In regards to other psychiatric presentations Mr Nesmith has spoken about being locked up in hospitals in various places in NSW at least on 2 occasions with him believing he was being censored for his beliefs and part of a greater conspiracy and coverup He was reluctant to give details of his time in hospital or precise locations He could list by name several antipsychotics used olanzapine risperidone quetiapine and the awful side effects experienced adding to his negative experience It does not seem he has ever taken antipsychotics longterm only in restrictive environments

There is no known history of his earlier years in the US before he moved to Australia He states he is estranged from his US parents and siblings because they dont believe in my cause He is adamant he does not want contact with them We have not found any longerterm friend or contact for any collateral history alas
