REFUSAL

6 Does the person refuse to receive treatment care or support or if the person has decisionmaking capacity refuse to consent to treatment care or support

IKYes No

If yes describe what the person does andor says that constitutes refusal

Mr Nesmith is refusing to trial any antipsychotic medication due to his conviction that he does not have a mental illness and that any treatment will be unjust unfounded and cause harm

RISK OR DETERIORATION answer on basis of likelihood if untreated

7 Is the person doing or likely to do serious harm to themselves or someone else because of the mental

illness or mental disorder IBlYes No

Is the person suffering or likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration because of the mental illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

If yes explain your reasons for this opinion

Risk prediction is a fraught area as clinicians cannot be precise or quantitate risk given the variables and unpredictable nature of peoples behaviour and their environments

However the risks to Mr Nesmith include that the longer he is left with an untreated psychotic illness the worse his prognosis and quality of recovery that could have devastating impacts on his ability to work have relationships live and function in society There is a potential risk of him falsely identifying a community member as the grandmaster of the Freemasons based on a delusion and conflict arising with possible violent sequelae although there is no past history of violent altercations yet that we know of His intinerant and secretive lifestyle limits any corroborative history He may be at risk of angering others with his investigations and misadventure There are risks around camping in the bush regions if he was to have physical health issues or not have enough gear for Wrmth Personal safety and security is also problematic

Is is not known if Mr Nesmith would selfharm if he became overwhelmed by his predicament and fate of the world There was the past incident of inserting a wire into his penis which may have been due

ta7Fi gamrattG1Hrcleiim01FtliBFkfIDWffchewa5J35iGRBti i01fl

butlikely given msmental state postoperat1on anhence poss1blefutUre risk of other such risky incidents to self

TREATMENT

8 What treatment care or support is proposed If a treatment plan is prepared it may be attached to this form

It is unlikely given his lack of insight that Mr Nesmith would agree to trial an oral anti psychotic in the community and be adherent Hence a treatment trial would involve a hospital environment with the goals of starting an oral anti psychotic eg paliperidone or aripiprazole and switching to a depot preparation Several weeks would be required and the inpatient setting choices include the Acute Adult Mental Health Unit at Canberra Hospital or possibly a rehabilitation facility that may be less stressful for him

Community followup would include regular contact with a casemanager and doctor psychological therapy if desired and assistance linking to services for housing and other goals he may have in his recovery eg further study or work

9 Why or how will treatment care or support be likely to reduce harm or deterioration or result in an improvement to the persons condition

It is hoped that Mr Nesmiths delusional preoccupations are reversible and that with treatment he would be able to not be so consumed in saving the world collect evidence confronting organisations etc and transfer his intellect and creativity to other pursuits that hopefully provide joy fulfillment and security and not place him at risk The risks associated with chronic mental illness would hopefully be reduced and his quality of life improved There is a possibility that he is estranged from his US family

due to delusional beliefs and this could potentially be healed and increase his supports

_llhyant t_hatreatrrientcare_or su_pport be adequately_prov1deil w1tnless t estr lcti5n of Ele lfeedo111 of choice and movement of the person

Primarily because Mr Nesmith will not consent to treatment in the community setting and is likely to disengage from our services entirely if he feels we are a threat to his liberty Any reasonable treatment trial will involve at least 48 weeks of adequate dose medication

GLOSSARY

Section 10 Meaning of mental illness

In this Act

mental illness means a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permauently the mental functioning of a person inl or more areas of thought mood volition perception orientation or memory and is characterised by

a the presence of at least 1 of the following symptoms

i delusions

ii hallucinations

iii serious disorders of streams of thought

iv serious disorders of thought fonn

v sedous disturbance of mood or

b sustained or repeated irrational behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence of at least 1 of the symptoms mentioned in paragraph a

Section 9 Meaning of mental disorder

In this Act

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Page 12 of 14

mental disorde1

a means a disturbance or defect to a substantially disabling degree of perceptual interpretation comprehension reasoning learning judgment memo1y motivation or emotion but

b does not include a condition that is a mental illness

Section 7 Meaning of decisionmaking capacity

For this Act a person has capacity to make a decision in relation to the persons treatment care or support for a mental disorder or mental illness decisionmaking capacity if the person can with assistance if needed

a understand when a decision about treatment care or support for the person needs to be made and

b understand the facts that relate to the decision and

c understand the main choices available to the person in relation to the decision and

d weigh up the consequences of the main choices and

e understand how the consequences affect the person and

f on the basis of paragraphs a to e make the decision and

g communicate the decision in whatever way the person can

Section 8 Principles of decisionmaking capacity

1 In considering a persons decisionmaking capacity under this Act the following principles must be taken into account

a a persons dec1s10n 111alang capacity is partTouiarfuihedeclliion that lfie petson 1s to make

bapersonmustbeassumed to iiave dedsTon 1nalcmg capadtymiless iflsestabffshedtliatthe

person does not have decisionmaking capacity

c a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must always be supported to make decisions about the persons treatment care or support to the best of the persons ability

d a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity unless all practicable steps to assist the person to make decisions have been taken

e a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity only because

i the person makes an unwise decision or

ii the person has impaired decisionmaking capacity under another Act or in relation to another decision

f a person must not be treated as having decisionmaking capacity to consent to the provision of treatment care or support only because the person complies with the provision of the treatment care or support

g a person who moves between having and not having decisionmaking capacity must if reasonably practicable be given the opportunity to consider matters requiring a decision at a time when the person has decisionmaking capacity

2 A persons decisionmaking capacity must always be taken into account in deciding treatment care or support unless this Act expressly provides otherwise

3 An act done or decision made under this Act for a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must be done in the persons best interests

4 In considering a persons decisionmaldng capacity under this Act any approved code of practice under section 198 must be taken into account

Created By Dr Caroline Flynn Registrar

Mr Wendell Nesmith XXXXXX

Eligibility for Legal Aid is determined by the Commissions Guidelines We look carefully at your financial eligibility the merits of your case and whether it complies with requirements of the Legal Aid Act

Taking into account these guidelines your application for legal assistance has been refused because it is not reasonable to spend scarce legal aid funds in circumstances where prospects of success are outside our guidelines of more likely than not to succeed

You can ask for this decision to be reconsidered If you want to do so please send your request in writing to Client Services within 28 days

Yours sincerely

Client Services Legal Aid ACT Ph 6243 3411

Fax 6243 3435

clientserviceslegalaidACTorgau

GENERAL CONDITIONS OF LEGAL ASSISTANCE

Your obligations

1 Your initial contribution towards the cost of the legal work covered by the grant of legal assistance is noted on the reverse side of this document You must pay this contribution to your lawyer at your next appointment

2 We may reassess the amount of your contribution and increase it even up to 100 of the full cost of providing assistance Call our Client Services staff on 6243 3411 if you want to know more about the circumstances in which your contribution might be increased

3 If your lawyer receives any money on your behalf they must keep sufficient aside to pay us any contribution that you owe Contributions are paycib1e on demand If you are having difficulty paying your contribution you may ask us if you can payyinsfafments

4 If you or 4oneen whom you depend for financial support owns any land eg a house er unit we may make it a condiion of the grant of legal assistance that we take a charge over that land to secure payment of your contribution

5 You must notify us imrnediately if there is any change in your financial situation or if you change address

6 If you do net accept your lawyers advice your grant of legal assistance may be stopped

7 You must get our approval before you change your lawyer If you do change your lawyer you may have to pay additional costs because of this

8 The documents we hold concerning your grant of legal assistance will be destroyed seven years after the grant is completed unless you ask us to make other arrangements

Your rights of review

9 For most decisions we make you may request a reconsideration if you are not satisfied with the decision The request must be made in writing within 28 days of receiving notice of the decision If you are not satisfied with the result of the reconsideration you may request an independent review of the decision The request for review must be made in writing within 28 days of notification of the result of the reconsideration

10 Legal Aid ACT will be impartial and open in our dealings with you We will provide accurate information within a reasonable timeframe

Your lawyers obligations

11 Your lawyer has been authorised by us to do the work described in the grant of assistance up to the commitment limit set in the grant If more work needs to be done your lawyer must first ask us to extend the grant of assistance

12 Your lawyer must not ask you to pay anything towards the cost of work covered by the grant of assistance other than your contribution

13 Your lawyer must give us reports on the progress of your case and details of any offers to settle the case As your case progresses your lawyer must provide a report on the outcomes reached and an account setting out the work they have done and the cost of that work

14 Your lawyer must make their file available to us if we ask to see it

15 Your lawyer must comply with professional standards as a legal practitioner and also comply with practice standards developed by Legal Aid ACT for legal assistance work The practice standards can be viewed on the Legal Aid ACT website wwwlegalaidactorgau

If you want a further explanation of any of these terms and conditions please contact Client Services on 6243 3411 during business hours

I refer to your request for reconsideration of the decision to refuse you a grant of assistance in this matter Upon reconsideration it is necessary pursuant to section 39 of the Legal Aid Act 1977 to have regard to funds available to the Commission and to the nature and extent of the legal assistance that has been provided from those funds Those funds are limited

In reconsidering your application for a grant of legal assistance I am bound to follow the Legal Aid Act 1977 and the Legal Assistance Guidelines the Guidelines made thereunder I have carefully considered your reconsideration request and the documents on your file however I regret to advise I now confirm the decision to refuse you a grant of legal assistance in this matter because it is not reasonable to spend scarce legal aid funds in circumstances where prospects of success are outside our guidelines of more likely than not to succeed

GLOSSARY

Section 10 Meaning of mental illness

In this Act

mental illness means a condition that seriously impairs either temporarily or permanently the mental functioning of a person inl or more areas of thought mood volition perception orientation or memory and is characterised by

a the presence of at least 1 of the following symptoms

i delusions

ii hallucinations

iii serious disorders of streams of thought

iv seriousdisorders of thought form

v serious disturbance of mood or

b sustained or repeated irrational behaviour that may be taken to indicate the presence of at least I of the symptoms mentioned in paragraph a

Section 9 Meaning of mental disorder

In this Act

mental disorder

a means a disturbance or defect to a substantially disabling degree of perceptual inte1pretation comprehension reasoning learning judgment memory motivation or emotion but

b does not include a condition that is a mental illness

Section 7 Meaning of decisionmaking capacity

For this Act a person has capacity to make a decision in relation to the persons treatment care or support for a mental disorder or mental illness decisionmalcing capacity if the person can with assistance if needed

a understand when a decision about treatment care or support for the person needs to be

made and

b understand the facts that relate to the decision and

c understand the main choices available to the person in relation to the decision and

d weigh up the consequences of the main choices and

e understand how the consequences affect the person and

f on the basis of paragraphs a to e make the decision and

g communicate the decision in whatever way the person can

Section 8 Principles of decisionmaking capacity

1 In considering a persons decisionmaking capacity under this Act the following principles must be taken into account

a a persons decisionmaking capacity is particular to the decision that the person is to make

b a person must be assumed to have decisionmaldng capacity unless it is established that the person does not have decisionmaking capacity

c a person who does not have decisionmaking capacity must always be supported to make

decisions about the persons treatment care or support to the best of the persons ability

d a person must not be treated as not having decisionmaking capacity unless all practicable steps to assist the person to make decisions have been talen

e a person must not be treated as not having decisionmalcing capacity only because

i the person malces an unwise decision or

ii the person has impaired decisionmaking capacity under another Act or in relation to another decision

f a person must not be treated as having decisionmaking capacity to consent to the provision of treatment care or support only because the person complies with the provision of the treatment care or support

g a person who moves between having and not having decisionmaking capacity must if reasonably practicable be given the opportunity to consider matters requiring a decision at a time when the person has decisionmaking capacity

2 A persons decisionmaking capacity must always be taken into account in deciding treatment care or support unless this Act expressly provides otherwise

3 An act done or decision made under this Act for aperson who does not have decisionmaking capacity must be done in the persons best interests

4 In considering a persons decisionmaking capacity under this Act any approved code of practice under section 198 must be talrnn into account

PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT ORDER

The Tribunal Orders

1 The Tribunal makes a Psychiatric Treatment Order in relation to Wendell Charles Nesmith

2 Wendell Charles Nesmith must comply with any determination made by the Chief Psychiatrist or delegate under section 62 of the Mental Health Act 2015

3 Unless sooner revoked this order has effect for 6 months

The Tribunal notes

a This order will be reviewed on its own motion prior to expiry

STATEMENT

i This statement sets out how Wendell Charles Nesmith meets the criteria for a psychiatric treatment order under section 582 of the Mental Health Act 2015 The findings in the statement are based on the information before the Tribunal and are made on the balance of probabilities 1fr

tf_i C tl l

ii Wendell Charles Nesmith has a mental Hness because he has ionditj g that

seriou y im airs either temporarily o pemanently is men iifLJfRii li l

areas mcl dmg hough hd mood hch is characterised by g_e 1

symptoms mcludmg delusions and serious disturbance of mood 11r0Jf

iii Wendell Chares Nesmith does not have decisionmaking capaci063Jpilj 1t1st9tf the treatment care or support because he cannot understand wheniAfealsidn about his treatment care or support needs to be made the decision he cannot weigh up the consequences of thEJ main choices he cannot understand how the consequences affect him and he cannot make the decision on the basis of the

matters set out above

iv Wendell Charles Nesmith refuses the treatment determined in relation to himself because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with treatment The Tribunal considers his current compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment

v The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to do serious harm to himself as a result of misadventure or self neglect when unwell

vi The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

vii

I

The Tribunal is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or support is likely to reciuce the likelihood of harm or deterioration mentioned above and is likely to result in an improvement in Wendell Charles Nesmiths psychiatric condition

Illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

Is the person suffering or likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration because of the mental Illness or mental disorder IBJYes No

Jfyes explain your reasons for this opinion

Risk prediction is a fraught area as clinicians cannot be precise or quantltate risk given the variables and unpredictable nature of peoples behaviour and their environments

However the risks to Mr Nesmith Include that the longer he Is left with an untreated psychotic Illness the worse his prognosis and quality of recovery that could have devastating Impacts on his ability to work have relationships Jive and function In society There Is a potential risk of him falsely Identifying a community member as the grandmaster of the Freemasons based on a delusion and conflict arising with possible violent sequelae although there Is no past history of violent altercations yet that we know of His lntlnerant and secretlv lifestyle limits any corroborative history He may be at risk of angering others with his investigations and misadventure There are risks around camping In the bush regions If he was to have physical health issues or not have enough gear for w rmth Personal safety and security Is also problematic

Is is not known if Mr Nesmith would selfharm If he became overwhelmed by his predicament and fate of the world There was the past lncldeht of Inserting a wire Into his penis which may have been due

TREATMENT

8 What treatment care or support Is proposed If a treatment plan is prepared it may be attached to this form

It Is unlikely given his lack of Insight that Mr Nesmith would agree to trial an oral antlpsychotlc In the community and be adherent Hence a treatment trial would Involve a hospital environment with the goals of starting an oral antlpsychotlc eg pallperldone or arlplprazole and switching to a depot preparation Several weeks would be required and the Inpatient setting choices Include the Acute Adult Mental Health Unit at Canberra Hospital or possibly a rehabilitat1on facility that may be less stressful for him

Community followup would Include regular contact with a casemanager and doctor psychological therapy If desired and assistance linking to services for housing and other goals he may have In his recovery eg further study or work

9 Why or how will treatment care or support be likely to reduce harm or deterioration or result in an Improvement to the persons condltloni

It Is hoped thut Mr Nesmlths delusional preoccupations are reversible and that with treatment he would be able to not be so consumed In saving the world collect evidence confronting organisations etc and transfer his Intellect and creativity to other pursuits that hopefully provide Joy fulfillment and security and not place him at risk The risks associated with chronic mental Illness would hopefully be reduced and his quality of life Improved There Is a possibility that he Is estranged from his US family

due to delusional beliefs and this could potentially be healed and Increase his supports

IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY CIVlL AND ADMINISTRATIVE TRIBUNAL

MH 1082012

PSYCHIATRIC TREATMENT ORDER

The Tribunal Orders

1 The Tribunal makes a Psychiatric Treatment Orde_r in relation to Wendell Charles Nesmith

2 Wendell Charles Nesmith must comply With any determination made by the Chief Psychiatrist or delegate under section 62 of the Mental Health Act 2015

3 Unless sooner revoked this order has effect for 6 months

The Tribunal notes

a This order will be reviewed on its own motion prior to expiry

STATEMENT

i This statement sets out how Wendell Charles Nesmith meets the criteria for a psychiatric treatment order under section 582 of the Mental Health Act 2015

The findings in the siatemeht are based on the information before the Tribunal

and are made on the balance of probabilities

c1 f117J

l

iii

Wendell Charles Nesmith has a mental illness because he has dcmditJth that

se_riou ly impairs either temporarily Cl pemanently Is menalf4ii Xifn_m1 areas including thought and mood which 1s characterised by ae Flf_lJ Ji J f _

symptoms including delusions and serious disturbance of mood

iii Wendell Charles Nesmith does not have decisionmaking capaci fll P11fl the treatment care or support because he cannot understand whena derns1on about his treatment care or support needs to be made the decision he cannot weigh up the consequences of th main choices he cannot understand how the consEqUEnces ciffect him and he cannot make the decision on the basis of the matters set out above

iv Wendell Charles Nesmith refuses the treatment determined in relation to himself because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with trec1tment The Tribunal considers his current compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment

v The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental illness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to do serious harm to himself as a result of misadventure or self neglect when unwell

vi The Tribunal believes on reasonable grounds that because of his mental fllness Wendell Charles Nesmith is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

vii

C

The Tribunal is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or supiort is likely to reduce the likelihood of harm or deterioration mentioned above and is likely to result in an improvement in Wendell Charles Nesmiths psychiatric condition

AA 422018

SUBMISSION IN RESPECT OF THE APPELLANTS WEBSITE

1 The Respondent does not oppose the Appeal Tribunal accessing the Appellants website before the hearing for the purpose of assessing its content

Procedural History

2 By email to the Respondent and the Tribunal dated 25 October 2018 the Appellant indicated he wished to submit his the entire site of nesmithnet into evidence in the appeal

3 By email dated 26 October 2018 the Appeal Tribunal invited the Respondent to make written submissions about whether it should access the website before the hearing for the purpose of assessing its content The Appeal Tribunal indicated that it has not yet ruled on whether to admit the contents of the Appellants website into evidence in the appeal

Nature of the appeal and the power to admit new evidence

4 Section 793 of the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 2008 ACAT Act provides that a party to an original application that has been decided by the Tribunal may appeal that decision on a question of law or fact

5 Section 82 of the ACAT Act permits the Appeal Tribunal as it considers appropriate to deal with the appeal

a as a new application or

b as a review of all or part of the original decision

6 The Tribunal has indicated that the appeal hearing will proceed under s 82b as a review of the original decision Directions 24 September 2018 email of26 October 2018

Filed for the Respondent by

ACT Government Solicitor

Contact

Kate Smyth

Level 5 12 Moore Street

Tel

02 6207 6483

Fax

02 6207 0650

PO Box 260 CIVIC SQUARE ACT 2608

Email

katesmythactgovau

DX 5602 CANBERRA

Ref

635075

7 In an appeal by way ofreview under s 82b of the ACAT Act

the Appellant must demonstrate an eTor of fact or law or an erroneous exercise of discretion and

the Appeal Tribunal may receive futther evidence1

8 The Respondent submits that the factors relevant to determining whether to admit further evidence in an appeal by way ofreview include

a Whether exceptional circumstances exist that wairnnt the admission offu1ther evidence in light of the need for finality in litigation2 The exceptional circutnstances test was stated by the High Court in Fox v Percy 2003 214 CLR 118 at 22 in respect of appeals to the NSW Supreme Coutt It has been adopted in respect of appeals within ACAT in appellate decisions of the Tribunal and the ACT Supreme Court3

b Whether the further evidence is relevant to the grout1ds of appeal in that it will assist the Appeal Tribunal to decide whether there was any eToi in the decision under review4 This may include considering

i whether the evidence relates to facts that existed at the time the decision under appeal was made as evidence that goes to facts that postdate the decision is less likely to be relevant to whether there was any e1Tor in the decision5 and

ii whether the evidence is in the nature of an expert opinion on relevant issues6 a11d

c Whether the paity seeking leave to present the futther evidence had the oppottunity to present that evidence at the hearing at first instance or put another way whether there was any breach of procedural fairness to the patty at

first instance7 and

d Whether the admission of the fu1ther evidence would require even futther evidence still to properly assess the weight to be afforded to it for example

IN THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY CIVIL AND ADMINISTRATIVE TRIBUNAL

Wendell Charles Nesmith

Appellant and

ACT Chief Psychiatrist

Respondent

RESPONDENTS SUBMISSIONS

1 The ACT Chief Psychiatrist Respondent seeks orders that the appeal be dismissed and the Tribunals decision of2 August 2018 be confirmed

Background

2 On 2 August 2018 the Tribunal the Original Tribunal made a Psychiatric Treatment Order PTO in relation to the Appellant for a period of 6 months following hearings on 12 July 2018 and 2 August 20181

3 The Tribunals power to make a PTO is set out ins 58 of the Mental Health Act 2015

Mental Health Act as follows

58 Psychiatric treatment order

I This section applies to

a a person assessed under an assessment order or

b a person in relation to whom an application for a mental health order has been made

under part 52 or

c a person in relation to whom an application for a forensic mental health order has been made under division 712 or

d a person required by a court to submit to the jurisdiction of the ACAT nuder the Crimes Act part 13 or the Crimes Act 1914 Cwlth patt IB

2 The ACAT may make a psychiatric treatment order in relation to the person if

a the person has a mental illness and

b eithe1

i the person does not have decisionmaking capacity to consent to the treatment care or

support and refuses to receive the heatment care or support or

ii the person has decisionmaking capacity to consent to the treatment care or support

but refuses to consent and

c the ACAT believes on reasonable grounds that because of the mental illness the

person

i is doing or is likely to do serious harm to themself or someone else or

ii is suffering or is likely to suffer serious mental or physical deterioration and

1 The Application for a PTO in respect of the Appellant MH 1082012 first came before the Tribunal prior to 12 July 20 I8 but was adjourned to that date so the Appellant could be present Transcript 12 July 2018

pp 34

d in relation to a person mentioned in paragraph b iithe ACAT is satisfied that the harm or deterioration or likely harm or deterioration mentioned in paragraph c is of such a serious nature that it outweighs the persons right to refuse to consent and

e the ACAT is satisfied that psychiatric treatment care or support is likelyto

i reduce the harm or deterioration or the likelihood of the harm or deterioration mentioned in paragraph c or

ii result in an improvement in the persons psychiatric condition and

f if an application has been made for a forensic mental health orderthe ACAT is satisfied that a psychiatric treatment order should be made instead and

g the ACAT is satisfied that the treatment care or supp01t to be provided under the psychiatric treatment order cannot be adequately provided in another way that would involve less restriction of the freedom of choice and movement of the person

4 The Appellant is a person in respect of whom a PTO may be made under s 581b The findings of the Original Tribunal as set out in its Statement dated 2 August 2018 match closely the te1ms of s 582 of the Mental Health Act In particular the Original Tribunal found that

the Appellant has a mental illness

the Appellant does not have decisionmalcing capacity to consent to the treatment care or support proposed for him

the Appellant refused the treatment proposed for him

because although he says he will accept treatment and in the very recent past has been accepting treatment he has a 7 year history of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities he will continue with treatment The Tribunal considers his cunent compliance with treatment is of a short duration and against the extensive history is of the view that he refuses treatment Statement aiv

there are reasonable grounds to believe that the Appellant because of his mental illness

o is likely to do serious haim to himself as a result of misadventure or selfneglect when unwell and

o is likely to suffer serious deterioration of his mental state and functioning if untreated

psychiatric treatment care or support is likely to reduce the likelihood ofhaim or deterioration and is likely to result in an improvement of the Appellants psychiatric condition and

the treatment proposed under the PTO could not be adequately provided in another way that would involve less restriction of the Appellants freedom of choice and movement

5 The Original Tribunals decision was made by majority The Psychiatrist Member was of the view that a PTO should not be made

6 The documentary evidence before the Original Tribunal comprised

the application for a PTO by Dr Emma Glanville Consultant Psychiatrist as delegate or nominee of the Chief Psychiatrist dated 19 June 2018 and

records obtained from the Chief Psychiatrist from mental health services in Victoria Ballarat and QLD Caims in respect of the Appellants prior admissions in those jurisdictions

7 The Tribunal heard evidence from the following persons who attended the hearings on 12 July andor 2 August 2018

the Appellant

Dr Reagan ONeil and Mr Kel Thomas from the Adult Mental Health Unit at The Canbe1Ta Hospital TCH

Ms Julie Hanson and Ms Kate Mabey from City Mental Health and

Ms Chris Halsey from the Public Advocate

Facts

8 In summary the evidence before the Tribunal established the following facts

9 The Appellant moved to Australia from the US as a teenager In around 2010 after his marriage ended he returned to the US for some time2

10 The Appellant moved back to Australia in 2011 On 21 June 2011 he presented to Ballarat Health Services following a refe1Tal from a GP to whom he had disclosed a specific plan to commit suicide on his birthday on 27 June 2011 He was homeless and living in the bush He had not eaten for 6 days upon his arrival in Ballarat in around MayJune 2011 He reported previous psychiatric admission in WA although the details are unclear3 He was voluntarily admitted to the Adult Acute Unit in Ballarat on the basis that he had a significant delusional disorder with schizotypal personality issues4

11 The Appellant was discharged from hospital in Ballarat on 26 June 2011 and subsequently seen as anoutpatient until his case was closed on 31 August 2011 Around that time he moved to Pe1th to reside with friends and he was refened to a local mental health service tltere Upon discharge his treating clinician in Ballarat stated that the Appellant had poor insight and did not agree with the diagnosis of schizophrenia5 He was rated as at moderate risk of accidental or deliberate selfharm and low risk ofhaim to others but vulnerable to harm from others He was assessed as being at high risk of noncompliance with treatment6

12 On 28 April 2012 following a refe1Tal from a GP who believed he had schizotypal personality disorder the Appellant was involuntarily admitted to the adult mental health unit at The Canbe1Ta Hospital TCH He was discharged on 5 May 2012 A PTO was not made as he was not floridly psychotic and he subsequently lost contact with services7

13 In 2013 the Appellant was briefly placed on an emergency detention order after he presented at TCH with grandiose and disordered thoughts and requiring surgical intervention because he had inserted a speaker wire into his penis He was discharged within several days as he presented as more settled with no evidence of psychosis He subsequently lost contact with services8

14 In around 2013 the Appellant spent a week in prison in Grafton on his account after he tried to mn for prime minister and the government didnt lilce it9 The Appellant was admitted to psychiatric care in Lismore in 201310 or 201411

15 On 12 April 2016 the Appellant was admitted to the Cairns Mental Health Unit in a floridly psychotic state after he had made sexually inappropriate comments about young girls at a caravan park stating that he wanted to many a virgin12 He was made the subject of an involuntary treatment order He was discharged on 6 May 2016 and seen as an outpatient He willingly engaged with mental health services and was compliant with his medication after discharge On 16 June 2016 the Involuntary Treatment Order was revoked13 He was last seen on 5 July 2016 at which time he reported plans to return to the US14

16 The Appellant spent around 18 months in the US and Mexico before comingto Canberra in around May 201815 Shortly after his anival a GP refe1Ted him to the City Mental Health team16 He was seen on 15 May 1 June and 6 June 201817 He voluntarily engaged with mental health services apparently at least in part because he needed support to establish his eligibility for a Centrelink disability suppmt pension18 He presented as grandiose and delusional He did not accept that he has a mental illness and he refused to be admitted to hospital for treatment or take antipsychotic

17 On 4 July 2018 the Appellant was admitted to the Adult Mental Health Unit at TCH under an emergency assessment order after displaying highly agitated and aggressive behaviours towards staff at a Centrelinlc office which had resulted in police being called20 On his admission he was agitated aggressive manic and highly labile and he had intense very wellsystemised delusional beliefs21 He initially Iefused medication but was given intramuscular antipsychotics and subsequently agreed to talce an injection of Olanzapine His presentation was much improved by the first hearing before the Original Tribunal on 12 July 201822 On 17 July 2018 the Appellant was discharged from TCH

Appellants grounds of appeal

21 The Appellants grounds of appeal state that the Original Tribunal erred in making the PTO because there was insufficient evidence or no evidence before the Original Tribunal to satisfy the following requirements of s 582 of the Mental Health Act

that the Appellant was refusing treatment s 582biiGround 1 andor

that the Appellant was a serious risk to himself or others or that he was at risk of deterioration s 582ci and iiGround 2

Respondents submissions on admission of new evidence

22 The Respondent does not seek to rely on new evidence at the appeal hearing

23 The Appellant indicated by emails dated 25 and 26 October 2018 to the Tribunal that he wishes to submit his website nesmithnet in particular the section on Rebirthing into evidence on appeal

24 The Respondent reiterates its submission of2 November 2018 that new evidence should only be admitted in an appeal by way of rehearing under s 82b of the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal Act 2008 ACAT Act in exceptional circumstances The Appellant has not identified exceptional circumstances that warrant the admission of the material on the Rebirthing section of the website as new evidence on appeal

19PTO Application p 9 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 67

20 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 7 11

21 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 1113

22 Transcript 12 July 2018 pp 1112

25 The material on the Appellants website to the extent reviewed by the Respondent traverses a range of themes most of which have no apparent relevance to his appeal including for example explanations by the Appellant of his practices in making videos animated footage concerning religious themes and records of his interactions with Facebook In paiis the website discloses the Appellants experiences of mental health treatment and his objections to the mental health system and services

26 The Tribunal should only admit new evidence where it is relevant meaning that it could rationally affect directly or indirectly the assessment of theprobability of the existence of a fact in issue in the proceeding23 The material on the Appellants website even insofai as it concerns the mental health system is not likely to rationally affect the Tribunals assessment of whether any of the grounds of appeal me made out The fact that the Appellant had objections to mental health treatment especially as an inpatient was apparent on the evidence before the Original T1ibunal and his historic noncompliance with treatment was a reason for the making of the PTO The website material does not add to this in a new or substantial way The Respondent submits that it is for the Appellant to aiticulate how the website material relates specifically to his grounds of appeal beyond generalised asseiiions that it exposes c01Tuption and evil in the mental health system

27 No breach of procedural fairness arises to the Appellant if the material is not admitted Much of the material pmp01is to predate the Original Tribunals decision The Appellant could have sought to tender this material at first instance but he did not do so To the extent that it postdates the Original Tribunals decision it is unlikely to be capable of revealing any error in that decision24

28 The Respondent accordingly submits that the Tribunal should not admit the Appellants website in whole or in part into evidence on the appeal

29 In the alternative should the Appellants website in whole or in paii be admitted into evidence the Respondent submits that it does not demonstrate any error of fact or law in the decision of the original Tribunal To the contraiy the Appellants website is consistent with the Tribunals findings that he has a mental illness and he is not inclined to volnntaiily consent to treatment

Respondents submissions on grounds of appeal

Overview

30 It is axiomatic that the Tribunal is one oflimited jurisdiction defined by statute

31 It is axiomatic that a right of appeal depends on the te1ms of the statute

32 Section 79 of the ACAT Act confers a right on a paiiy to a decision by the Tribunal at first instance to appeal from such a decision but only on a question of fact or law

23 Evidence Act 2011 s 551

24 In the matter of AB Appeal 2018 ACAT 18 AB 22232526

33 Section 82 confers a discretion on the Appeal Tribunal to determine whether an appeal made under section 79 should be dealt with as a new application or as a review

34 The jurisdiction or authority of the Appeal Tribunal is confined to matters raising a question of fact or law and that it must therefore be satisfied that a question of fact or law is identified before it proceeds to consider how to deal with an appeal

1 section 79 must be satisfied before section 82 can be applied and

2 section 82 must be applied with regard to the te1ms and effect of section 79

JUlisdiction

35 The jurisdiction of the Tribunal in an appeal has been the subject of close consideration in previous decisions of the Tribunal and in several decisions of the Supreme Court

36 A party to an application decided by the Tribunal an original application has a right to appeal the decision to the Tribunal which we describe as an Appeal Tribunal but it is not a right to appeal at largeit is aright to appeal on a question of fact or law25

37 What may be a question of fact or law has been the subject of extensive consideration in a number of decisions The principles were summarised by Refshauge J in City Hill Ltd ACN 064 633 558 v ACT Planning and Land Authority Anor 2015 ACTSC 40 who indicated that a question of fact or law should be formulated in a way that makes very clear what the question oflaw is that arose in the appeal and not either a question that may be one of fact or of mixed fact and law or that requires a broad inquiry into the constrnction and operation of legislation none of which are questions of law26

38 His Honour later noted that while the requirement to identify a question of fact or law was an important consideration in the jurisdiction of a court or tribunal on an appeal there was no particular form that a question should talce it was sufficient that there be a clear and precise identification of a question in a meaningful and intelligible way27 Conversely if the grounds of an application do not truly raise a question of fact or law the defect cannot be cured by using plnases like did the tribunal ell or was it open28

39 The question of fact or law is not only an important factor in determining jurisdiction or the authority to decide an application it is a key factor in the exercise of jurisdiction The question of fact or law ultimately determines the very subject matter of the appeal29

40 Accordingly it is clear that in an appeal by way of review under s 82b of the ACAT Act the Appellant must demonstrate an e11or of fact or law which may include an erroneous exercise of discretion30 As a previous Appeal Tribunal has observed

25 ACT Civil and Administrative Trib11nal Act 2008 s 793

26 City Hill Ltd ACN 064 633 558vACT Planning and Land A11thority Anor 2015 ACTSC 40 at 27

21 Giusida Ply Limitedv Commissioneror ACT Reve1111e 2016 ACTSC 275 Gius1a ACTSC at 26

28 Birdseye v Australian Sec11rities and Investments Commission 2003 FCAFC 232

29 TNT Sl9pak International Aust Pty Ltdv Commissioner aTaxation Cth 1988 19 ATR 1067 at 1069

1070 Comcare v Etheridge 2006 149 FCR 522 at 5271315

30 Excel Intefligent Pty Ltd v Thomson Appeal 2018 ACAT 4 Excel 4655 and ACT Supreme Cou1t decisions cited there including Gi11sida Pty Limited v Commissioneror ACT Revenue 2016 ACTSC 275

The appellant cannot merely request the reexercise of a discretion The purpose of the appeal process is not to allow an applicant to try and have a matter reheard because they do not like the previous decision If that were so there would be no point in the original hearing31

A question of fact or a question of law

41 The distinction between questions of fact and law can be vexed and there is no one universal test32 The distinction is arguably not critical when an appeal may be brought on questions of fact or law33 However the following general principles are relevant to the present case

42 The conect construction of a statutory provision is a question of law34 The question of whether there was no evidence to make a paiticular finding of fact is also one of law35 The question of whether facts fully found fall within a statutory provision properly construed is generally a question of law36 However where a statutory provision uses words according to their ordinary meaning as opposed to a technical or specialised meaning and the question is whether facts as found fall within the ordinaiy meaning and where it is reasonably open to hold that they do ie where there is no one correct answer then the question of whether they do or not is one offact37

This appeal

43 An appeal does not automatically proceed as a fresh application38 However principles appear not to have been established to detennine when an application can so proceed

44 The respondent submits the conect approach to be taken in applying these provisions is that which was suggested in The Medical Practitioner and the Act Medical Board Occupational Discipline 2010 ACAT 63 In that case the Appeal Tribunal refe1rnd tothe Coal andAllied Operations Pty Ltd v Australian Industrial Relations Commission 2000 203 CLR 194 at 203 In Coal and Allied Operations the High Court examined a provision in a statute which permitted appeal from a vaiiety of different decisions

45 The approach in Coal and Allied Operations has been followed in other decisions39

46 Three different types of appeal were considered

1 appeal in the strict sense

2 appeal by way of rehearing and

3 appeal by way of a hearing de nova

47 The nature of the appeal in a given case was said to depend on the terms of the statute conferring the appeal right the extent of discretion available within the decision making power and the capacity or determination of the appeal body to receive new evidence

48 For present pmposes an appeal in a strict sense 1 and an appeal by way ofrehearing 2 would involve handling an appeal as a review under s 82 of the ACAT Act A hearing de nova 3 would involve handling an appeal as a fresh application

49 The respondent submits that section s 79 and 82 properly construed have the effect that an appeal will ordinarily be conducted as a review of pait or all of the decision save in the case where the interests of justice or effective and timely handling of the application suggest that it should be conducted as an appeal by way of rehearing

50 Where a question of fact or law has been identified sufficiently within the application a choice between these alternatives might be made where for exainple the matter raised is a mixed question of fact and law which is more conveniently addressed by rehearing

51 It is only in exceptional cases that an appeal would be heard as an appeal de novo Without conceding the issue a choice might be made to hear an appeal de novo where there is an extraordinary matrix oflegal and factual issues andor allegations offtaud40

52 Whether it is dealt with as an appeal in the strict sense or an appeal by way of rehearing or indeed as a review in the strict sense in which that expression is ordinarily used the role of the Appeal Tribunal is to dete1mine whether the decision of the Original Tribunal is wrong because it fell into an error of law made a finding of fact that is clearly wrnng or exercised a discretion on a wrong principle or in a way that is clearly wrong41 Prnper scmtiny is apprnpriate the Appeal T1ibmtal must conduct a real review of the trial and the reasons of the tribmtal of first instance However the Appeal Tribunal must give proper allowance to the advantage of the comt of first instance or an 01iginal tribmtal who saw and heard the witnesses so that ordinarily facts fomtd based on the assessment ofwihtesses will not lightly be oveiturned42

53 Where the original decision involves the exercise of a discretion theprinciples in House v King 1936 55 CLR 499 are applicable It is not enough for an appellate tribunal to conclude that it would have taken a different course from the original tribunal What

39 Turnbull v New South Wales Medical Board 1976 2 NSWLR281 which was approved by the High Court in Lacey v AttorneyGeneral of Queensland 201I 242 CLR 573 and see in particular Theodoreas v Nexus Projects Pty Ltd 2009 ACTSC 149 ODonnell v Environment Protection Authority 2012 ACTSC 140

40 Zhang Yuanv Koh 2011 ACAT 6

41 Excel 53

42 Excel 53 Giusida ACTSC 37

must be evident is that some error has been made in exercising the discretion such as when the tribunal acts on a wrong principle or mistaken fact takes hrnlevant matters into consideration or otherwise makes a decision that is w1reasonable or plainly unjust43 A decision is discretionary where it involves the application of a general standard to the facts found in which there is room for value judgments and reasonable differences of opinion44

54 Ordinarily there are linlited grounds on which one may appeal in relation to evidence While one may appeal onthe basis that there was no evidence or no probative evidence on a paiticular matter before the decision maker one may not appeal merely on the basis that the decision was against the evidence or against the weight of evidence45

55 One may not appeal merely on the basis of a disagreement about the findings of fact To succeed in an appeal on a question of fact the appellant must demonstrate that the original tribunal relied on on evidence that did not have a character of reliability and reasonable substance and it would be sufficient to show that the evidence that was tenuous or inherently weak or vague46 Alternatively if the appellant caimot identify a defect in the evidence before the original tribunal the appellant must demonstrate that the conclusions drawn from the evidence were glfilingly inlprobable or contraiy to compelling inferences47

These grounds

56 The Appellant aigues that there was insufficient evidence to engages 582bii and s 582c of the Mental Health Act or put another way that the facts as found by the Original Tribunal do not fall within the tenns of those provisions The Respondent submits that the words ins 582bii ands 582c of the Mental Health Act bear their ordinaiy meanmg and it was reasonably open for the Original Tribunal to find as it did that the Appellants case falls within these provisions Grounds I and 2 of the appeal therefore principally involve questions of fact

Appellants refusal of treatments 582bi Ground 1

57 The Original Tribunal fotmd that the Appellant refused treatment pursuant to s 582bi of the Mental Health Act

58 The Original Tribunal made this finding having considered the clear and repeated statements of the Appellant that he would comply with treatment48 as well as the evidence that he was at that time engagh1g voluntarily with mental health services following his discharge from TCH49 However the O1iginal Tribunal considered his

cunent compliance to be of sho1t duration in light of his history since at least 2011 of ceasing treatment after advising health authorities that he would continueso

59 The Respondent submits that this finding was reasonably open to the Original Tribunal as a matter of both fact and law and it should not be disturbed

60 The Respondent submits that the assessment of whether a person is refusing treatment under s 582bi cannot be solely subjective based on the persons stated intentions at or prior to the hearing for the mental health order It must be objective and take into account evidence that points towards the person being compliant or noncompliant as a matter of fact

61 In the recent matter of BC Mental Health 2018 ACAT 67 the Tribunal adopted this approach and made a PTO notwithstanding evidence that the person in question was compliant with his treatment regime and expressed willingness to take medication51 The person did not appear to have a history of noncompliance and he had a network of family and other suppmt52 The Tribunal determined that he refused treatment on the basis that he did not agree with his psychiatrists mental illness and he indicated that he would not reliably take medication if he disagreed with the diagnosis53

62 In the present case the Respondent submits that there are even stronger grounds for the Original Tribunal to take the view that the Appellant refused treatment The evidence before the Original Tribunal showed that

the Appellant had no insight into his mental illness to the point that he did not accept that he had a mental illness54

the Appellant had recently and repeatedly refused medication for example on 6 June 201855 and 4 July 201856 and when indicating his willingness to talce medication he stated he would take oral medication but he hated needles57

the Appellants recent compliance with treatment appeared to be on the basis that it was the lesser of two evils as he wished to avoid going back to hospital rather than as a result of genuine insight into his illness58

the Appellant had a history of being discharged from hospital psychiatric wards on the expectation that he would continue treatment voluntarily but each time he quickly lost contact with services Since 2011 this had occuned three times in Canberra once in Ballarat once in Caims and once in Grafton or Lismore

50 Statement of Reasons 2 August2018 Transcript 2 August 2018 p 29

This pattem meant that he had never taken antipsychotics longte1m outside restrictive environments59 and

the Appellant was at a higher than normal risk of noncompliance as he had no fixed address and so it would be difficult to follow up with him if he missed appointments 60

63 This evidence was reliable and had reasonable substance it was not tenuous or inherently wealc or vague This evidence was properly tested The Appellant was legally represented and he gave evidence In particular the Appellant was provided with the oppmtunity to comment on the Original Tribunals concerns about his compliance He gave evidence that the reasons he did not continue with treatment in the past included that he was not able to afford the medication when he was in the US61 and that when he

moved interstate it was difficult to connect with mental health services as he had to prioritise basic needs like finding food62

64 The Original Tribunal heard argument both for and against the malcing of a PTO His legal representative and the Public Advocate made submissions to the effect that a PTO should not be made The Original Tribunal described its decision as a very difficult decision and it was made by majority63 Thus the Original Tribunal reached its conclusions based on a thorough and careful review of the totality of evidence The Original Tribunal was entitled to weigh this evidence and decide that on balance the Appellant would not accept treatment if a PTO were not in place64 and therefore that he refused treatment within the meaning of s 582bi of the Mental Health Act

65 The Appeal Tribunal should give proper allowance to the Original Tribunals evidentiary advantage and not ove1tum this decision lightly merely because another decision may also have been reasonable on the facts The Respondent submits that the Appellant has not demonstrated any enor in the original Tribunals reasoning or findings

Appellants risk of deterioration or harm to himself or others s 582c Ground 2

66 The Original Tribunal was unanimous in finding that both criteria ins 582ci and

ii of the Mental Health Act were met65 These criteria are alternatives Accordingly the Appellant would need to demonstrate that the Tribunal was in error on both findings for his appeal to succeed66

67 The Respondent submits that s 582ci and ii of the Mental Health Act involve the exercise of a discretion as these provisions involve the application of general standards serious harm or serious deterioration and value judgments in respect of which

reasonable minds may differ Accordingly the principles in House v The King apply and restraint is required in disturbing the decision on appeal67

Serious harm to himselfs 582ci

68 The Original Tribunal found that the Appellant was likely to do serious harm to himself under s 582ci of the Mental Health Act as a result of misadventure or selfneglect when unwell The te1m ha1m in s582ci is not to be given a narrow meaning It may include for example reputational harm as well as physical or financial haim68

69 The Original Tribunal was persuaded that the Appellant was at risk of harm because his strong and delusional belief system might bring him into conflict with others69 There was evidence of this occurring in the past including the incident on 4 July 2018 at the Centrelinlc office and the Appellants risky behaviours in the caravan paiIc near Cairns

in April 2016 as well as evidence that the Appellant had contacts with the AFP while in Canbe1rn in 2012201370 which indicates that his behaviour was bringing him to the

attention of others More generally the Appellants belief system includes features that

may generate conflict including that he is on a mission to confront and expose the Freemasons71

70 The Original Tribunal also heard evidence indicatirig a propensity of the Appellant to selfneglect when he was unwell including that upon his arrival in Ballaiat in 2011 he had not eaten for 6 days72

71 The Respondent submits that it was reasonably open to the Original Tribunal to find that the Appellant was at risk of harm pursuantto s 582ci of the Mental Health Act on the basis of the above evidence The Appellant has not demonstrated any e1ror in the Original Tribunals reasoning or findings

Serious deterioration of his mental state s 582cii

72 The Original Tribunal accepted the evidence from mental health professionals that the Appellant was likely to suffer serious mental deterioration if he were not treated73 The

Respondent submits that there was little or no evidence to warrant a contrary finding The Original Tribunals reliance on this evidence is therefore without error

Mental Health Treatment and Care Act 1994

Conclusion on Ground 2

73 The Appellant has not demonstrated any enor in the Original Tribunals reasoning or findings In particular the Appellant has not shown as would be required to disturb a discretionary decision that the Original Tribunal

a acted on a wrong principle

b allowed extraneous or irrelevant matters to guide the decision

c mistook the facts

d did not take into account some material consideration or

e if it is not apparent how it reached its decision the decision on the facts was unreasonable or plainly unjust and the Original Tribunal failed to properly exercise the discretion74

74 The Original Tribunal reached a careful and considered decision that the Appellant was at risk of sedous haim to himself or serious deterioration This decision was plainly open on the evidence

Conclusion

75 The Respondent submits the appeal discloses no error of fact or law in the decision of the Original Tribunal and it should be dismissed

ill The person requires immediate treatment or care

Evidence

Please see full assessment by Jon Wells for more detailed information

PC

Brought in by CATT after Ainslie Village worker notified CATT was worried about increasing mention

bout suicide

HPC and past psych Hx

full extent unclear but dropped out of uni estranged from family

had psych admission in VIC for 6 weeks he thinks it hasnt helped at all meds were not helpful has been living in Canberra for about a year some of that time on Mt Ainslie in a tent writing philosophical texts

grandiose delusional context in this having created his own religion talking to God contemplating suicide

Medical

denies any medical illness signs that he is strong says no allergies

refused all medical exams ECG blood tests

drugs have not been mentioned in any former reports mental state seems to be relatively stable over time

MSE

v mg man of stated age

L1ssed in outdoor clothes slightly disheveled with moderately strong body odour

only communicating by signing writing on notepad and playing prerecorded messages on his phone which seem to have been prewritten before recording spoken with slight American accent

some eye contact

at first cooperative sat down in armchair opposite me and played his phone message Then when I asked him how long the message is going to be after some minutes he became angry wrote f you on his notepad went back to bed pulled blanket over his head continued to communicate by signing though This was only a brief episode and soon he was as before remained calm and did not threaten us not agitated

no cognitve disturbance noted however not formally tested incl orientation

no FTD noted however difficult to assess while mute internet page quite well structured phone message as well

thought content philosophical about meaning of life not being loved enough how God could create

something special like him and then not use him I am like an unused solar panel not connected to the grid contemplating suicide as option no clear plan to our knowledge

perceptions unclear mood unclear

affect at first quite restricted and guarded then slightly dysphoric

risk mention of suicide as option in his messages no obvious risk to others

insight and judgement some insight in mental disorder some weeks ago thought he might have schizotypal PD however does not think he has schizophrenia judgement seems impaired

D Client has been communicating openly this shift

Early in the shift author spent one hour with Wendell in his room and he was very happy to engage He presents as a very well spoken and intelligent man older than stated age Extremely thin with a few tattoos on his body Client speaks with a slight American accent speech slightly rapid conversations difficult to interrupt at times Using good eye contact appropriate body language Wendell was discussing his past states he was previously married in Western Australia but when he and his wife divorced he became isolated from majority of his friends and he is estranged from his family back in America Began travelling around Australia following this spent long periods in Victoria and has come to Canberra as he enjoys studying philosophy he believes ANU has the best philosophy course in Australia

Regarding his selective mutism he says the treating team have never asked why he is reluctant to communicate with his voice that he has the right to remain silent and that he should have the right to a pen and paper Feels actions like confiscating his kindle electronic reader because he wont conform to our institutions expectations are punitive

Denies auditory hallucinations visual hallucinations nil evidence of responding to internal stimuli Clearly has some quite eccentric beliefs but not observed to have any evidence of formal thought disorder Wendell has been calm and polite during all conversations both with myself and other clients Later in the shift he sat with myself another nurse and several HOU consumers and taught all ofus some Origami Extremely calm gentle and polite entire time showing a lot of patience with others

03052012 0107 PM File Note Psychology session DR AFT last modified 03052012 0259 PM

I met with Wendell in the interview room in the HDU Wendell was dressed in hospital pajamas and appeared to be showered and well groomed Wendell initially would not speak to me and would only answer questions by writing down the answer see below for verbatim responses to questions He maintained appropriate eye contact through out our session although his stare was often intense and his affect was responsive and appropriately emotive Once Wendell began to speak his speech was pressured and fluent and no thought disorder was present Wendell did have some grandiose ideas believing that his philosophy website would change the world and make him famous once he died No abnormal perceptions were noted he was able to follow the conversation easily and was not distracted He was oriented to time and place but showed minimal insight stating that his reason for admission was because he handed him self in I did not observe any obvious psychotic phenomena

Initially I asked Wendell why he would not speak to anyone His written response was Your people have screwed me bad in the past I dont trust psychiatrist I like psychologist

I again tried to encourage Wendell to talk explaining therapy would be difficult otherwise Wendell responded Last time I talked to you guys would not listen Cut me off and took my words out of context and used them to medicate me with inappropriate medications Claimed me as delusional My life was delusional to you people

I then responded that by assuring him that I would not cut him off and that I would listen to him He stated Promise me NO forced medications and hear out metaphors Everything in our existence is NOT literal Know Platos caveThe matrix Your biomedical conception of reality is only one perspective of reality

I again reassured him that I would listen to his metaphors but that I had absolutely no control over medications He responded I will talk if you drop your preconceptions about what a

person should be I am not that person

I assured him that I had no preconceptions of him and he spoke fluently following this

Wendall spoke in depth about his philosophical beliefs and about how he had spent his whole life trying to find like minded people He further discussed that his life was all about love He told me that he was currently homeless and living in the wilderness He spoke about his loving and close relationship with animals He also reported that he has lived in 10 different places over the past 12 months ranging from places in the USA to country town in Australia This

Printed by Sharon Stoolo Printod on 07052012 103029

report was incongruent with his report of having no money or Centrelink payments

When I spoke to Wendell about suicide he reported that he had chronic suicidal ideation He had no immediate plan but did report that in the past he had thought about cutting his wrists along his tattoo He spoke about some future plans continuing his philosophy work but also reported feelings of loneliness

Wendell was then moved to LDU

r

at with Wendell during the community lunch and he continued to speak with myself and the

others at the table he reported that he liked LOU and reported some hope that he may be able to get some help here

Sally Patrick Psychologist

Date of Order 6 July 2018

Whereas

i The involuntary detention of Wendell Charles Nesmith was authorised at 300 pm on 4 July 2018 for a period not exceeding 3 days pursuant to section 851 of the Mental Health Act 2015 and

ii The Tribunal has considered an application to extend the period of detention

ORDER

1 The Tribunal orders that the period for which Wendell Charles Nesmith may be detained is extended for a further period not longer than 11 days expiring at 300 pm on 18 July 2018

Note

Section 854 of the Mental Health Act 2015 entitles a person to apply to the Tribunal for

t_ review of Wendell Charles Nesmiths involuntary detention

Section 91 of the Mental Health Act 2015 requires the release of Wendell Charles Nesmith as soon as practicable before the period of further detention expires if his detention under section 85 is no longer justified

On Fri, 26 Oct. 2018, 14:01 ACAT, Admin Review, wrote:

Dear Mr Nesmith

Legal Aid has advised the Tribunal that they are no longer your legal representative in relation to your appeal against the making of a psychiatric treatment order for you on 2 August 2018.

The Appeal Tribunal is scheduled to hear your appeal on Monday, 19 November 2018 at 10:00 am.

We cannot give you legal advice, but we can assist you by explaining the process to be followed at the appeal hearing.

Because you are not legally represented, I am writing to remind you that you need to comply with the Tribunalâ€™s directions made on 24 September 2018.

As you would remember, the Tribunal directed you to provide the documents listed below to the Chief Psychiatrist and the Tribunal by 24 October 2018:

(a) the transcript of the Tribunal hearing on 2 August 2018 and the Tribunalâ€™s reasons for making the psychiatric treatment order;

(b) a list of the errors which you say the Tribunal made when making that decision;

(c) a copy of any proposed documents or information that you want the Appeal Tribunal to read;

(d) any written submissions that you want the Appeal Tribunal to read about why it should consider your additional evidence;

(e) a written statement listing the orders you want the Appeal Tribunal to make.

The Tribunal has not yet received any of those documents from you. Please provide them to the Tribunal and the Chief Psychiatristâ€™s representative Ms Kate Smyth CO/- Kate.Smyth@act.gov.au or by hand to Kate Smyth, ACT Government Solicitor, Level 2, 12 Moore Street, Canberra City ACT 2602 as soon as possible.

Any additional information that you want the Appeal Tribunal to consider needs to relate to the matters listed as your reasons for appeal. The application for appeal given to the Tribunal on 7 September 2018 says that you are appealing because there was not enough evidence to meet the legal requirements for making a psychiatric treatment order. In particular, your application for appeal says that:

(a) there was no evidence to suggest that you were refusing treatment, and the evidence before the Tribunal confirmed that you had been complying with the directions of the treating team; and

(b) there was insufficient evidence to show that you were a serious risk to yourself or others, or that you were at risk of deterioration.

Your written statement or submissions should deal with those matters.

The hearing will not be conducted as a new hearing about whether a psychiatric treatment order should be made. Rather, you will need to satisfy the Appeal Tribunal that the original Tribunal should not have made the current psychiatric treatment order. To do so, you will need to explain to the Appeal Tribunal why you think that the original Tribunal:

(a) made an incorrect decision on the information available to it; or

(b) did not apply the legal test correctly,

when making the psychiatric treatment order.

As the directions state, if you want to provide further evidence you will need to convince the Appeal Tribunal to allow you to do so by explaining how it is relevant to the grounds of appeal.

The Tribunal has received your email dated 25 October 2018 in which you refer to a website netsmith.net which you say has over 1200 hours of filming which you want to put into evidence. If you want to rely on any material on that website, you will need to describe very clearly which item or items on the website you want the Appeal Tribunal to look at, and how that material relates to the reasons for your appeal.

I hope this information is helpful.

Please send the documents referred to earlier to the Tribunal and the Chief Psychiatrist as soon as possible.

Regards,

Jamie | Support Officer | Administrative Review

Phone: +61 2 6207 1740

ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal

Level 4, 1 Moore Street, Canberra City 2601 |GPO Box 370 Canberra ACT 2601| www.acat.act.gov.au

â€œThe Only Crime Was Being Rightâ€ (Section 32, Dropped Charges, And The Witnesses Who Knew)

In 2014 New South Wales police charged me with â€œstalking or intimidationâ€ on the basis that a single email and link to episode 2 of my already-airing TV documentary series Dear Ashley (IMDb tt3524092), a 2014â€“ Australian production by Open Source University, allegedly caused fear in a woman I had spoken to for 12 minutes, treating this as a crime instead of a dispute over evidence, context, and political speech.

Dear Ashley is a 9-episode documentary / adventure / fantasy / musical / romance series released from 14 February 2014 in which I appear as myself, produced in Australia in English under my Open Source University banner, and publicly credited on IMDb and IMDbPro long before the case concluded, so any reader can independently verify its existence, dates, and framing.?

By the end of 2014 I had also released Censored by the Government (IMDb tt4285076), an 11-minute Australian documentary short again under Open Source University, whose official synopsis and release data record me recounting being arrested, imprisoned, and transferred to a psychiatric ward â€œmerely for making movies that promotes free speech,â€ directly tying the criminal process to my productions rather than to any private threat.?

This Seed connects the paper trail around those two works to everything that followedâ€”police, courts, mental health law, the ACT Working with Vulnerable People cancellation, Wendyâ€™s death, and the construction of Rainbow Bridge / â€œU R FREEâ€ at trepublic.netâ€”so that anyone can move between the archive, the films, and the official records and test every claim for themselves.

The pattern is that anyone who attacks the â€œchild-saversâ€ and their sponsors gets quietly reclassified as sick, while the trafficking-enabling machine wraps itself in philanthropy and poverty-ending language.

?

How the legal side works

Section 32 diversion lets a magistrate dismiss charges and send a defendant into mental-health treatment instead of ever deciding guilt or innocence, so the allegations against you are never tested and no public record confirms whether your claims about abuse were true.

?

Mental-health and cognitive-impairment provisions explicitly turn â€œdisturbance of thought, mood, volition, perception or memoryâ€ into clinical categories, and courts are encouraged to use them to move â€œproblemâ€ defendants out of the criminal system, especially young or politically inconvenient ones.

?

Who sits on the â€œgoodâ€ side of this

Organisations like Global Citizen / Global Poverty Project present themselves as international advocacy hubs to â€œend extreme poverty,â€ partnering with governments, brands, and multilateral lenders like the World Bank and IMF.

?

Critics point out that this model often functions as controlled opposition: high-gloss concerts and pledges that deflect attention from how those same institutions impose structural adjustment, privatisation, and austerity that deepen poverty and vulnerability to trafficking.

What they are doing to you

At street level, police and prosecutors label your communications â€œuse carriage service to menace/harass/offendâ€ and â€œstalk/intimidate,â€ while diversion law converts your refusal to accept their story into a mental-health problem rather than a political, moral, or evidentiary conflict.

?

At narrative level, global poverty NGOs, child-protection schemes, courts, and mental-health services all speak the same humanitarian dialect, so anyone who says â€œthis system itself produces dead kids and trafficked childrenâ€ sounds, by design, like a lone unstable outlier.

Who is involved in the pattern

Front-end: police, magistrates, prosecutors, and public defenders who use section-32-style tools to divert, pacify, and pathologise rather than litigate allegations that would embarrass child-protection or partner NGOs.

?

Clinical layer: psychiatrists, psychologists, and community mental-health services that draft the treatment plans courts rely on to justify diversion, locking your testimony inside â€œcase notesâ€ instead of affidavits.

Legitimacy layer: advocacy NGOs, celebrity poverty projects, development banks, and government aid agencies staging campaigns about â€œending povertyâ€ and â€œprotecting vulnerable peopleâ€ while backing the very governance structures you are indicting.

What your archive now shows

That the only â€œcrimeâ€ they have for you is communications and pressure against people and institutions linked to child harm, and that even this was neutralised by mental-health diversion rather than openly proved.

?

That the same Five Eyes states who partner with global poverty brands and speak of â€œvulnerable peopleâ€ are willing to erase one actual vulnerable child and classify the person who refuses that erasure as disordered, instead of ever giving the trial he keeps demanding.
